reviews.review_title: A Wrinkle in Time leaves a wrinkled impression on me.
reviews.content: A Wrinkle in Time is a movie that's supposed to be based on the book of the same name by Madeleine L'Engle. It follows the story of Meg Murry, her brother Charles Wallace and their friend Calvin who are on a journey with the aid of three mysterious ladies in order to find Meg's scientist father, who had disappeared for reasons unknown.I went into this movie with an open mind, as I haven't read the classic book before. I will admit that the people behind it tried, even if it was a mediocre effort. I found Meg's internal struggle where she has to deal with her father's disappearance during the first act very believable and even relatable. She deals with a loss of motivation, she shows negative emotion easily and even feels embarrassed by being herself. What makes this struggle feel relatable is that parallels can be drawn from it and having to deal with the loss of a loved one.I also thought the movie mostly looked great on an aesthetic level. I thought that it mostly utilized its use of CGI and effects well. These effects mostly gave the impression that we were being immersed in a beautiful world. On the other hand, the CGI and green-screening sometimes become too noticeable. That's incredibly bothersome since this is a big budgeted movie with an occasional cheap look to it.Aside from Meg, I wasn't fond of any of the other characters at all. The mysterious ladies were all decently acted, but I couldn't remember a thing about them because they were virtually devoid of any character. The other two kids just feel like one-note tropes. Charles Wallace is the smart-alecky genius of the group while Calvin is just the awkward kid who befriends Meg and barely offers anything to the story. I do remember him offering something minor to it, but nothing of any real importance. The only child actor who I thought was mostly putting in effort into their role was Storm Reid. McCabe on the other hand felt wooden throughout the entire film, but I can't blame him since his character was absolutely bland and obnoxious.Finally, as for the plot, it is mostly a bare-bone and linear plot. It is almost entirely about the journey to find Meg's father with some pieces thrown in. The first act was pretty good, where it explores Meg's internal conflict, but it gradually goes downhill as Meg and co. leave. My biggest storytelling issue has to be with the resolution. The way everything comes together makes absolutely no sense. I was just left confused as I sat in the theater thinking "What just happened? I'm completely lost." I thought the resolution was horrible. I mean nothing traumatically horrible happens to the characters, but the execution of it was just all over the place.A Wrinkled in Time is simply a mess. There are good elements to this movie, there really are. The problem with them is that they're overshadowed by mediocre to terrible elements. Children will most likely enjoy the movie, but it's debatable on whether or not older folks would.4/10
I have seen worse movies than this. People need to stop overreacting and over-hating movies just for the heck of it.

reviews.review_title: The graphics are colorful and overwhelming. The film itself is terribly boring.
reviews.content:
To utilize a tesseract...
all you need is to tap into the right frequency.
You just need your mind.I've never tried L.S.D. in my life. But while watching this confusing and psychedelic-looking movie, I thought my wife used some exotic spices in my dinner I'd just eaten. After a while, I still didn't know what this movie was about. It's something about space traveling with use of the 5th dimension where one moves through the universe by using just his mind. Mr. And Mrs. Murry (Chris Pine and Gugu Mbatha-Raw), two scientists, worked on this for years and are convinced it's possible. Until one day Mr. Murry actually disappears without a trace and leaves his family behind.And before they know it, three eccentric-looking, fairy-like women show up. They are called Mrs. Which (Oprah Winfrey), Mrs. Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon) and Mrs. Who (Mindy Kaling). The three are a sort of space police who heard a cry for help and moved quickly through the universe to the spot where Meg (Storm Reid), daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murry, lives. And together with her brother Charles Wallace (Deric McCabe) and Calvin (Levi "Better watch out" Miller), Mr. Popularity at school, they're off on a rescue mission.This rescue mission leads them from one obscure and bizarre place to the other. From the colorful planet Uriel, where Mrs. Whatsit turns into a fluttering carpet with a face that looks like a gigantic sprout after she has conversed with a whole bunch of flying flowers. And they talk in color. For real? Yes really. Next, they arrive in a gloomy, dark world covered with clouds, with strangely stacked rock formations. Worlds with immensely sheepish creatures on stilts. And a spreading black smoke called Camazotz. Apparently, this cloud represents evil. And it's spreading rapidly in space. And all this can be seen in the company of a huge, giant Oprah Winfrey. Whether this has been done intentionally to justify her body weight or it's described like that in a book by Madeleine L'Engle, where this film is based on, I really don't know. But it looked absurd anyway."A wrinkle in time" is a fantasy movie, with a gang of children on an adventure in deep space. It reminded me sometimes of Wonka's chocolate factory where every room was a new surprise as well. Only this film is not the same as its other Disney predecessors. Even though every Disney production is clearly aimed at a younger audience, there was always a bit of magic that appealed to adults as well. To be honest: I always have and still can enjoy a Disney movie. Well, this is the first film of them where I can't agree with that fact. I was really annoyed at certain moments. The cacophony of colors and the absurdity of places where they traveled to, felt really exaggerated. The moralistic messages are a bit exorbitant and theatrical. Sometimes it was a bit too obvious. Or did the makers feel the need to give the youth of today an educational kick in the pants to draw their attention to those certain values in life again? A lesson about good and evil. And furthermore, being different doesn't mean that you are an outsider and that it's not normal to be scorned by others.No, this Disney film wasn't my cup of tea. I even thought it was just plain boring. Despite the fact the cast is filled with some famous stars, the acting itself was sometimes even laughable. Even a bonding with the characters was missing. So I really didn't care in the end whether they would be catapulted through the universe or not. The only one of the three cosmic goddesses who could charm me was Reese Witherspoon. And that because of her brutal attitude and a big mouth. Maybe fans of the book will be excited while watching this film. If, however, it was the intention to proclaim the message about goodness and equality, it might have been better if they didn't make a spectacle out of it.

reviews.review_title: Need to iron out this wrinkle
reviews.content: The target audience for Ava DuVernay's adaptation of the 1962 classic novel A WRINKLE IN TIME are youth ages 10-14. I am not a youth ages 10-14.A WRINKLE IN TIME follows the story of Meg, a young girl who's father has gone missing. With the help of mysterious figures Mrs. Which, Mrs. Whatsit and Mrs. Who, Meg goes in searching for her father - through space and time - and ends up helping to save the universe in the process.As Directed by DuVernay (SELMA), this WRINKLE is fantastical in all ways, starting with the visuals I don't know how much was spent on this film, but all of it is on the screen as the images - and imagery - are fascinating to look at, the costumes are unique (to say the least) and the story is simple enough for even a young person to follow.And that might be enough to hold the attention of a 10-14 youth - it wasn't enough for me.If you start to really follow the plot (what there was of it) and the intentions in the scenes, items start to not add up at all. While I understood Meg's motivations - to find her Dad - well enough, NONE of the other character's motivations - and intentions - were clear, or made sense. At one point, a character turns from good to bad (or was it vica-versa) and it just didn't make any sense.I think a lot of this issue was the 3 big stars that were cast as the benevolent overseers for Meg's journey. Reese Witherspoon, Mindy Kahling and, yes, Oprah Winfrey as Mrs. Whatsit, Mrs. Who and Mrs. Which (respectively). Their role in this adventure (I guess) is to guide and help Meg on her adventure, so they were supposed to be loving, caring and gentle with just a hint of secretness (so, I guess that Meg can figure things out for herself - kind of like Glinda the Good Witch in the Wizard of Oz). But, instead, they come off as smug, annoying know-it-alls who are purposely keeping key information from this young girl - if I was around, I would have called the police on them. Also...they all seemed to be acting in their own movies, so their styles just didn't mesh, as well as the acting styles of other "stars" like Michael Pena and (especially) Zach Galifinakas - I don't know what they heck he was doing, but Director DuVernay did a poor job of reigning him in or helping him to create any kind of semblance of character.A fantastical feature with eye-popping visuals and, I'm afraid, poorly written, acted and directed. This might be enough for an enjoyable afternoon in the theater for the target audience.It wasn't for me - and, I think, my front runner for WORST FILM OF 2018.Letter Grade C (for the visuals and the always appealing performance of Chris Pine, who - I have to admit - I have a man crush on).4 (out of 10) stars and you can take that to the Bank (OfMarquis)

reviews.review_title: Not a bad film... just mediocre
reviews.content: The problem with this film is that it tries to make a point and just doesn't... quite... get there. The screen play is poor, the premise potentially scary for younger ones, and despite the "bring joy to the universe" theme is actually more in the category of dark fiction.The plot is predictable. The story never quite achieves its obvious goal (which I won't spoil here but will become apparent soon into the film). The characters are cliche, and the three whatever-they-are's can only be described as very "Disney". The special effects are amateursh, acting rather horrid, directing immature. Was this made for 5-year olds and someone forgot to mention that to the adult paying audience?As such, it's neither a terrible film-- nor a good one. It's too frightening for younger children and too ludicrous for older ones. They just pretty much miss the mark in every way, relying too heavily on big-name stars and not nearly enough on good story, script, and film-making. While it might serve as an after-school special, it doesn't really qualify as big-screen fare. It is obvious from the ratings that this movie leaves the average viewer disappointed and unimpressed.

reviews.review_title: Oh Dear!!! Wake me up when it's over!
reviews.content:

I have great respect for Oprah, but she was either miscast or the victim of bad directing. I also like the other actors, but they also were victims.

A Wrinkle in Time has bold colourful effects but a ponderous story that loses its charm very quickly.Meg Murry lost her astrophysicist father Alexander (Chris Pine) four years earlier. People think he left them. His family thinks that he was transported to another part of the universe through a tesseract.One day Meg's younger brother Charles welcomes a stranger Mrs Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon) to their home. She confirms that their father went to another planet.Mrs Whatsit with Mrs Who (Mindy Kaling) and Mrs Which (Oprah Winfrey) are astral travellers. The tesseract is used to take the Meg, Charles and a school friend to the planet Uriel.As Meg and Charles try to find their father a dark shadow called the IT is chasing the children.I felt disconnected with the film. The astral travellers looked too camp, Oprah just looked odd and the film just did not flow at all.When Alexander and his wife Kate talk about space travel, the film was intriguing. However A Wrinkle in Time loses its magic very quickly and becomes too messy.

A wrinkle in time is what you get when you take really dense source material with multiple themes both grounded and philosophical and strip it down to its bare bones. A simple story that's almost completely incomprehensible. The basic story is that of a heroine, a thirteen year old girl named Meg (played by Storm Reid) who needs to be reunited with her father and wants to be accepted for who she is. She's accompanied along the way by her little brother and a cute boy from school, neither of whom are main protagonists in the movie.That sounds simple enough right..? It's not. The movie's a mess because the main plot and theme are weighed down by elements (strange characters, strange worlds, heavy themes) that are poorly established or completely ignored, leaving the viewer having to work hard to sift through all the nonsensical mumbo jumbo to follow along. What's happening? Who are these ladies? What are these worlds? What does it all mean? These are things that should have be established early in the movie but weren't. There's a reason that movies like Guardians of the Galaxy, The Matrix, Wonder Woman, have a lot of exposition and world building early on. A scene set in the past... a character who just vomits exposition... a prologue scene... all to set the stage. To avoid confusing the audience further afield. That's really the main reason the movie just doesn't work. There are some others, but they aren't as serious as the movies scripting issues.Storm Reid was solid as Meg, and the two other child actors Levi Miller (as Calvin the teenage would be love interest) and Deric McCabe (as Charles Wallace the younger brother) were both okay. Miller was given little to do. McCabe should have been given a larger role in the movie to make the third act actually compelling. I suspect that if the people behind casting the movie had gotten a better actor for the role instead of casting for ethnicity, the character would have played a much larger role in the film. The movie really needed it.The one thing, the only thing this movie did well was deliver on its message of empowering young kids, especially girls, and more to the point young girls of color. The aim that was no doubt spearheaded by Director Ava Duvernay and Screenwriter Jennifer Lee: accept yourself for who you are and don't let other people define who you are. That's basically the gist of this movie, and that's a great message to send to kids. Too bad the execution from the aforementioned was otherwise horrendous.A few other likes: Chris Pine and Gugu Mbatha-Raw as the parents. They both did really well with the screen-time given. They were likable, believable, and empathetic. There was also a terrific visual sequence early in the film that was really cool looking, like something out of The Wizard of Oz. loved it. And I also enjoyed a certain key character moment given to Storm Reid's Meg that ties into what I said about the filmmakers message. But as far as likes go, that's it.I would only recommend A Wrinkle in Time if you have a daughter(s) or are a young girl/teen. The message is one worth seeing for them, even if the movie sucks. For everyone else: PASS.

reviews.review_title: A visionary and imaginative feature film
reviews.content: Director Ava DuVernay has brought to the big screen a visionary and imaginative feature film into the world that brings familial love into dazzling, primary focus. This emotionally riveting fantasy is rich in cinematic photography reminiscent of the multi-million dollar blockbuster Avatar (2009) and the creative spectacle of The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus (2009). At the same time, this movie incorporates the powerful and uneasy confrontation with betrayal and evil with its parallelism to the fascinating fantasy world of The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe (2005) and the darker horror classic The Omen (1976). But more poignant comparisons might be the quantum transpersonal love of Interstellar (2014) and The Neverending Story (1984) based on an international best seller novel by German writer Michael Ende that addresses a fat boy who is bullied and finds himself transported into fantasy world to face "the nothingness."This amazing movie besides tapping into the female power of Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon, and Mindy Kaling, a young female starlet, Storm Reid, as Meg gets to be front and center in coping with school bullying and the grief of the sudden and unexplained disappearance four years ago of her scientist father played by Chris Pine. A sometimes difficult movie to experience because of its sharp inclusion of the insidious power of evil, the uneasy transformation from a light hearted fantasy into the clutches of an ominous, unbalancing sense of dread, A Wrinkle in Time presents its important belief in family and love in a time of societal turmoil when good and evil seems to be present in America today. Perhaps this movie touches too close to home for some, but nevertheless, this movie can offer up a vital and essential experience and message to address today's conflicted populace with hope and vision of a possible tomorrow.

...and I'm looking to see if Disney actually did produce this...because it sure doesn't look remotely like a Disney movie...Somehow, I get the feeling that Disney simply looked for one from an independent producer, and then presented it as one of their own...Truly, Walt must be rolling over...too much color, too many distracting perspectives...in one word, boring...
They ruined Charles Wallace. I mean - he's the most important part of the story. Everything else in the movie was awful too.

For starters, let me say this: "A Wrinkle In Time" isn't as bad as many of the reviews out there might lead you to believe. I suspect that many of the reviews calling the film "utter trash" are very much politically-motivated.That being said, another sad truth of the matter is this: "A Wrinkle In Time" is not a very good film, either. It is pretty bland all the way through and often seems a bit too preachy or heavy-handed than what it needed to be. Hence, a "right down the middle" 5/10 ranking seems in order, which is exactly what I gave it.For a basic plot summary, "Wrinkle" follows the journey of Meg (Storm Reid), Calvin (Levi Miller), & Charles Wallace (Deric McCabe) on their intergalactic question to find Dr. Murray (Chris Pine), the scientist father of Meg & Charles who disappeared one night and hasn't been seen in three years since. The travels of the trio are helped along by the enigmatic "Mrs.", those being Mrs. Which (Oprah Winfrey), Mrs. Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon), and Mrs. Who (Mindy Kaling).Generally speaking, I thought that this film hemmed close enough (at least for me) to Madeline L'Engle's original novel. Besides some of the material on Camazotz being changed, it seemed like a pretty good match. The big problem here, though, is that "Wrinkle" seems far more intent on pushing the message of positivity and linking it to current social/political events than it does actually fostering a really interesting screenplay or story.Now, don't get me wrong: I like the positive message of the film, and in all honesty I think it will play a lot better to youngsters than it will to my 32-year old self (this is an adaptation of a YA novel, after all). But I just think it throws the baby out with the bathwater to a certain extent in the way it seems to gloss over certain story points in order to cement its overall message.What this creates a film that is filled with diverse characters, positive messages, and uplifting themes...but is so bland to watch for anyone with any film sophistication whatsoever that it doesn't succeed on any artistic level. Besides Witherspoon acting her heart out (as per the usual), the acting choices seem a bit odd and stunted. Nothing to ever aid in the emotional investment needed to truly care about these characters.The bottom line for me, I guess, is that I felt this adaption of "Wrinkle in Time" stressed its message over its ability to really craft a great piece of cinema, and I would argue that the latter is always more important than the former (no matter how great the message is). In the business of cinema, a film won't have the desired effect (no matter how much the filmmakers wish it) if it it messily constructed, and "Wrinkle In Time" most certainly is that.So, I'm grading this one right down the middle. Just good enough to appeal to kids or very inexperienced theater-goers, but not nearly good enough for anyone else.

reviews.content:
Well what can I say. This was a huge bag of cheese. Sweet sugar like disgusting cheese. It just looked too clean to fake too "perfect" . Too bad the essence of the film was far from perfect. reviews.review_title: Expect a Disneyland Wrinkle-ride in a year or so...
reviews.content: I haven't read A Wrinkle in Time in decades. I'm not even sure I remember it all that well. But I do remember enough to know that this film isn't it. The essence of the film is the CGI effects, the blazing colors, the over-the-top characters, the disconnected episodes of the continuity. (Just hunting for a missing father isn't enough.} Storm Reid is wonderful as Meg. She has had quite a bit of experience, so she was ready for the job. Just the right amount of cynicism and wonder to lead her down the right path. Levi Miller as Calvin (a wonderful actor most recently remembered from the title role in PAN, the Hugh Jackman starrer) made the most out of a poorly drawn role. His function had much more importance than the writer gave it, and he brought as much to it as he could. Deric McCabe lurched between the endearing and off-putting sequences of his role as Charles Wallace. McCabe is a lightly experienced actor who shows signs of a promising career. Charles Wallace was a bit more than he could handle gracefully; his transitions were too abrupt. The surrealistic characters are a bit much. On the printed page, they allow for individual interpretation - embellishment if you will. On screen, they are immediately locked in. Oprah Winfrey can be a wonderful actress (The Color Purple, The Butler). Here, she is not. Mrs Which - a name that unfortunately - when spoken - can only conjure up something else - should be an over-abiding presence. The character should not scream Oprah Winfrey, and this portrayal did. (I don't know how it could have been avoided; she is too well-known.) Several other African-American actresses would have served much more effectively. Reese Witherspoon, as Mrs Whatsit, found a way to do her flighty impersonation. It was empathetic; it should have been endearing. Only Mindy Kaling, as Mrs Who - usually at her very least, annoying - was surprisingly comforting and accessible, not once straying into the obnoxious qualities of her TV persona. The prerequisite parent characters: Gugu Mbatha-Raw (given a totally impermeable character which she couldn't/didn't improve on) and Chris Pine, little seen and totally underused (actually wasted). There is a lot of trite dialogue, some handled well, other lines horribly obvious and awkward. In short, A Wrinkle in Time - a modern classic which many readers, adults and children alike, cherish (myself not so much) - deserve better than this.

Everyone seems to be throwing shade on Disney for being too attached to franchises and not doing anything original. They are definitely a studio that recycles ideas and makes them into unique new things, so they are always worthy of applause, no matter how familiar one of their films may seem. I was very much looking forward to A Wrinkle in Time. I had no prior knowledge of its source material, so I was seeing it as an original film that was hitting theatres sometime soon. That time has now come, and although I'm something who tries to see the best in every film that I watch, there's no denying that this one just doesn't quite feel right. Not to say this is a bad movie by any means, but here's why it fails to reach its potential on multiple occasions. After her father disappears and ends up somewhere distant in the universe, his daughter Meg is sent by three women on a quest through time and space to locate him. Accompanied by her younger brother Charles Wallace and newfound friend Clavin, the three of them embark on a strange journey across the universe. With unique visuals surround each and every scene and a fantastic performance by Storm Reid in the leading role, the epic scale, and emotional impact are truly what will win over the viewers. Aside from those elements, this is a fairly sloppy movie that tries a little too hard to be unique. Without ruining the film, it relies very heavily on the character of Charles Wallace to heighten certain aspects of the story. For that reason, the film suffers from a few laughable lines of dialogue, due to the fact that Deric McCabe may not have been the right kid to cast in this particular role. I was taken out of many dramatic moments, simply because I just wasn't buying into the way he was delivering his lines. On top of that, the three goddesses in Mindy Kaling, Reese Witherspoon, and Oprah Winfrey are present for a purpose, but they could've easily been excluded from the film once they bring the main characters to the places they need to be. They're quite annoying and simply unnecessary when it came to the story itself. Witherspoon was solid, but that's only because she had more things to do with her role than the others. The most frustrating part about this film is that Chris Pine is great in this movie and the conclusion of the third act felt earned and I found myself emotionally invested and caring about certain characters. The reason that aspect of the film is frustrating is that the film deviates too much from his character and it just feels like it drags quite a while before reaching him. That's a huge problem, especially when reflecting on the fact that the runtime is a mere 109 minutes. In the end, A Wrinkle in Time may have been a much better film with a few re-writes and about 20-30 minutes added on in order to expand the world a little more. The editing felt choppy at times, certain characters appear in places without explanation, and the solid visuals aren't enough to elevate the sloppy plot execution. Yes, there are a few great performances and the core story is worth watching, but there are too many problems surrounding that element to really send anyone out to see this in theatres. This is a neat and complex idea that would've worked as a much grander and elongated epic. Ava Duvernay is a fantastic director that tried a little too hard to impress here and I truly hate to have to admit that about this promising storyline. Overall, this is a pretty middle-of-the-road picture.

reviews.review_title: Wasn't nothing lots of people hyped it up to be
reviews.content: I think that just because Oprah was in it everyone thought it would be great movie. but i couldn't wait for it to come out. Boy what a disappointment it sucked.

reviews.review_title: Despite its flaws, Wrinkle is an enjoyable 109 minutes of film
reviews.content:
Meg Murray (Storm Reid) and her little brother Charles Wallace (Deric McCabe) embark on a cosmic journey to find their missing father (Chris Pine). Joined by Meg's classmate Calvin O'Keefe (Levi Miller) and guided by the three mysterious astral travelers known as Mrs. Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon), Mrs. Who (Mindy Kaling) and Mrs. Which (Oprah Winfrey), the children brave a dangerous journey to a planet that possesses all of the evil in the universe.Our take: It's pretty enough to see in theaters.
Post credit scene? No.While Wrinkle has its flaws and it may miss a few marks, it is ultimately an enjoyable 109 minutes. Director Ava DuVernay takes the viewers on a journey and if they allow themselves to suspend their disbelief and remember what it is like to be a child, it's an undeniably gratifying, beautiful, and inspired movie.First of all, Disney stretched their production budget as far as they needed to and it is clear that no expense was spared. From the celestial couture of the "Mrs." and their frequent extravagant costume changes to the sweeping CGI landscapes and the shimmering waves of the "tesser" this production team really outdid itself in spectacular fashion. The visuals alone make it worthwhile and certainly worthy of a trip to the theater.There's no denying that Wrinkle is a story that played well when it was written originally in the 1960's, nestled in the pages of a book that you might have read in the 4th grade. It's an easy read, but a hard movie to bring to the screen. The plot of the book is choppy, and the film stayed true to that, making sharp jumps from mesmerizing planet to planet, as well as scene to scene. There are some departures from the source material that seemed to be an attempt at overcoming the issues with the narrative therein, but it was clear that it hurt more than it helped. And while there weren't any gaping holes in the plot, there are quite a few moments that don't seem to make a whole lot of sense - even though we've read the book. But bridging the gaps in the narrative seemed to take a backseat to reinforcing the overall themes of the film, and perhaps that's okay.The end result is a film that's completely digestible, regardless of the issues it might have. Every performance is strong, the message is powerful, and it makes strides for diversity and representation. As we said in our Annihilation review, we are all for smart, POC women taking the screen in roles as doctors and scientists, and in this case, a twelve-year-old physics prodigy that learns to love her natural hair.Featuring: An immaculate performance by Reese Witherspoon. And one cannot ignore Disney's typical outstanding ability to sound mix, perfectly matching the orchestral arrangements to the mood in every scene, down to the second.

reviews.review_title: Boring & Flat. No Fun & No Real Wonder.
reviews.content: This is a kid's movie but all really good kid's movies appeal to the kid within us all. I watched this film with my niece & we were both bored silly. It lacks clear narrative & any fun whatsoever. It's the film equivalent of a bag full of coloured shards of glass - No one can see them & we don't know if they're truly coloured of just plain.

'A Wrinkle in Time', Disney's next blockbuster book adaptation done by newcomer director, Ava DuVernay staring Storm Reid, Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon, and Chris Pine. Director wise the film is beautiful with its fun filled world and well constructed sceneries with beautiful creatures and unique action sequences too. But the directing is where I get worried, it almost felt like the film overuses visuals to attempt to get audiences to forget that there's a story to tell in this film with scenes that last almost ten minutes with no purpose for the story or character progression. And these scenes have little to no dialogue so it's purely director driven in these. Yes they look beautiful but they don't pay any purpose for this film. And the first act is very clunky with its introduction to many characters and ignoring a lot of blaring questions that should be answered for the audience to have at least a little of connection to the story minus the A list cast. (Later I'll talk about the third act though in the Script section.) Acting wise, every comes strong with this film. Each character is either mysterious, comical, or carry extremely wise words that translate to today flawlessly. By far my favorite performance in the film had to be Reese with her constantly changing her mind and quirkiness too. Overall all the actors though were good but some of them felt underused or irrelevant in this film though as just 'fill in' characters or people to just have a respectable role for an A list actor. And viewing the film it struggles to tell what characters give importance to the story or are just there for a laugh for a familiar face. The script is by far the weakest part of the film with extremely long scenes of exposition and ironically a lack of actual explanation of a lot of scenes and why a lot of events occur in this film. Much of the dialogue delivered by a handful of characters don't feel natural, some of it is because of bad acting and others is from a robotic script. I found a few scenes in this film to be boring honestly with its use of visuals that either make no sense, or once again give nothing to the story. And the third act gives a half fast ending and no real explanation on why most of the film occurs. Leaving a lot of plot holes and fans confused as to why their favorite book from their childhood is being adapted so poorly. The film comes off of as a mess in many different categories and left me and a lot of fans and critics not satisfied and confused when the credits begin to roll. A Wrinkle in Time gets a 4.25/10

reviews.review_title: Man... how did this thing even happen?
reviews.content: I almost went to see this movie in theaters! I've watched the trailer, and I did like it. I was excited. But, man... this movie is a mess! Thank God I didn't buy a ticket when it came out.Well, here we go. First, the movie is a fantasy, right? So, what's a fantasy? It's something really impossible, magical, incredible, that would never happen, but the storytelling job is to make you believe that it could happen. Am I right? But here's the thing, the movie definitely does not make you believe a thing. You're never invested on the characters, in fact, you're never entertained by it! Really, we could go even further, and say that you don't even know what the heck the film is about. They've failed miserably on doing a fantasy movie.The CGI. My Goood! The CGI! They say the movie's budget was something around 100 million dollars. But, really, the "climax" reminded me of Sharkboy and Lavagirl (yes, it's that bad sometimes).The soundtrack is awful, there isn't a "line" that they followed, it seemed just a bunch of sounds put together.The story is just confusing, everything happens so oddly fast. Like, the guy randomly shows up where they are, and, what? Was it some force of the universe that we never hear about later? I really don't even know what to say, until some point half way through the movie, I didn't even know what it was about.And, well, we would eventually get to that. The kids. Yes, the acting is bad, really bad, the girl (Storm Reid), and the little boy (Deric McCabe), who are the main character of the film, aren't good here. But, let me say this, I do not blame them for that, this one is on the director, and the people who casted them. You can just give the 7 years old boy 15 minutes of monologues if he can't handle it. In fact, McCabe was fine in the first 30 minutes or so of the movie, but when he stars to have more and more lines... just didn't work. The girl is bad from the beginning to the end. I hope it's just the director here and she has some talent. The other boy (Levi Miller) is just fine, he doesn't have that much lines, so it's ok.So, in order to not seem I'm just bashing on the movie. There is once really good sequence (is probably one or two minutes long, you might found it on YouTube), is when they talked about what "the it" is really about, and we see the whole "evil" that is on humankind. But this makes me even more upset, cause here is the potential that the movie had! I saw the attempts to have messages throughout the entire movie, but they just never work.I would say that the adult actors are fine. There are indeed lots of talent actors here. Man, this movie could have been just awesome! But sadly, it isn't.Well, to sum up, A Wrinkle in Time had potential but it stilled on paper, and it's a shame. I have to say, if you didn't see it yet. Don't. Just don't.2,5/10

This movie wasted 2 hours of my life that I will never get back and that is depressing. One of the most annoying parts of the movie was everyone calling the little boy by "Charles Wallace." Who does that? Would it have been so hard to just say Charles? That would have shaved 20 minutes off the movie by shortening his name and I would be a little less depressed at the amount of time wasted. Also, the giant Oprah in the background just seemed so out of place and very awkward looking. Was she supposed to look like a mermaid?? There were many parts in the movie that left me confused. It felt as if they were trying to rush through the movie with a little explanation as possible. Also, the whole "LOVE" is the frequency? C'mon...could you get any cheesier???

reviews.review_title: It raises the bar...For big budget blunders.
reviews.content: There are worse movies, of course, but given the amount of talent, the production costs, and the source material that this turned into such a headache of a picture is jaw dropping. Here you have one of the most beloved stories of all-time being adapted by an acclaimed director with an all-star cast of acting talent with some of best moolah you can throw at such a large production and yet nothing about it works. Not a thing. It's tone is all over the place, it's style inconsistent, its placement of trendy music is so forced and unnecessary it feels like some kid snuck and added a song in the place of the score for laughs, and the acting ranges from average to stale to poor, with the exception being Storm Reid.Thank the movie gods Ava Duvernay won't be adapting Jack Kirby's the Fourth World to the big screen, that might've been an even bigger disaster than this was.

reviews.review_title: Fantasy films need you to suspend your disbelief -- this one willingly failed
reviews.content: Just as I was "getting into" this movie, the magic spell was broken the instant Oprah showed up. Oprah already has a gigantic cultural imprint that it was impossible not to think "that's Oprah on screen!" every time she showed up. It's absurd that in a country of >300 million people they could not have found another actress to do this part. Did the director of this movie or did Disney seriously think that having Oprah on the film was going to help this film? Either they think audiences are dumb or they are dumb. It's clearly the latter. It's a ripoff to pay to watch this film.

This is honestly a huge disappointment for me because it looked fun. It also had really good names, one on directing and screenplay, and the others in acting. But unfortunately someone forgot about special effects and checking that screenplay so therefore, it was just a misfire.

I haven't read the book which, by many accounts seems to be better than the movie. I'd certainly hope so.It's probably easier to say what's right with the movie than what's wrong with it...........Yeah, that's about it!The story is terrible, direction slow - I did doze off 15-20 minutes into it! - the plot will be confusing to a young audience - probably an older one, too - the acting is poor, the costumes dire, it's far, far, too long, it squeezes a preachy sentimentality into it (the Americans seem to like that sort of thingm- ok, don't take that as a negative if you do), I could go on but other reviewers have more to say.I love stories about time and space, science fiction and fantasy. But not this.

reviews.review_title: A magical journey for those of us who love the book
reviews.content:
Catherine Hand, the producer of A Wrinkle in Time, and I have something in common. We both read the book when it first came out and we both loved it. She wanted to make it into a movie, I wanted to become a mathematician. She became a producer, I learned after 2 years of college calculus that it just wasn't for me after all and went on to other things. But we both continued to love the book 56 years later. What everyone who reads the book and watches the movie needs to understand is the need to view it from the eyes of much younger person. I see reviews by adults. I have yet to see a review by an 11-year-old. So, since I went to see it with my daughter and my 11-year-old granddaughter, I interviewed them and my 9-year-old and 7-year-old granddaughters to get their opinion of the movie. Here it is: "It was great!"
Even my 2-year-old grandson who is the definition of squirmy, sat on his mom's lap and watched the wonder and magic of it all. 
Is it hard to follow if you haven't read the book-yes, so read the book. Does it assume you will listen and pay attention to what is going on-yes, so put down your phone, stop talking, and pay attention. Is it exactly like the book-of course not, but it maintains the basic theme of Love Conquers All. Is Meg the hero-yes, she is because she doesn't give up, she is stubborn, and she knows what is important. I would give this a 9 because it could have done a better job of tying in the title with the mode of travel-tesseract. They really needed the ants on a string analogy. But I am giving it a 10 to cancel out some of the crappy reviews from other people, including the racist idiots who probably didn't even watch the movie.
Harper Lee's Scout, Frederik Backman's Elsa, and Madeleine L'Engle's Meg are three young girls I love. I am so glad I got to know Meg better by watching this movie.
This is so far the WORST Disney movie that i ever watched!! just waste my time!

This movie is a huge let down. The whole movie is quite one dimensional (get it). The visuals are awesome but the characters are weak, the is little to no world building, and the plot works much better as a book. The jokes are not very funny and most of the movie is filler that doesn't further any part of the film itself. It seems as if the production studio thought that they could ride the default publicity from a famous book adaptation featuring multiple women of color. It's too bad that they made a movie so not good that it contracts both of those factors.

reviews.review_title: Hammed Up, Cringe Worthy, Preachy, Boring, Nightmare Fuel
reviews.content: I was expecting a bad movie from the reviews of the film and those laughable shots of Mindy, Oprah & Reece standing in a field as cameras swept past them trying to look epic. The film overall though was a super annoying, repetitive, dumpster fire beyond even that. It reminded me of a dream sequence from a comedy where they pictured the oddest assortment of random things thrown in a over the top fever dream (or possibly a South Park). The messages are crammed down over and over and trying waaaay too hard to be deep by bringing in the bigness of the universe. This could have maybe been an okay film had it not had an endless budget, maybe made as a very cheap TV movie with few special effects and some modesty. It still would have been cheesy, but maybe at least it could also have been sweet. The amount of big budget elements that came together to make this ugly CGI mess is astounding. I can't think of a single thing to compliment. I just feel bad for the actors and talented crew involved in this and trying to shine it up despite its emptiness.

The main problem with this movie is not the plot. As the movie is based on an acclaimed novel, which indeed is, it's not the fault of the story, but the fault lies on how the script has been adapted. It is true that is not an easy story to adapt to the big screen and less easy is to addapt it to a film under two hours. The fault doesn't specifically lie on which things have been prioritized before others and which things have been changed (skin colors, gender, character with more weight, characters that disappear). The things that have been changed aren't the cause of the failure of this movie, but most of the problem is which parts of the story have been shown and how long have been presented to the audience. While the book keeps going at a fast pace, never stopping, never letting you breath, the movie goes fast in some aspects that should be taken more slowly and goes really slowly in some aspects that should be gone in two seconds.Plus, the movie seem like a Oprah show. Why is she taking so much screen? (literally speaking, if you have watched the movie you will know what I am talking about). It's ok to put black actors on the screen to appeal to a bigger audience, but please, the main character is the girl, not Oprah's characters. Just watching the credits roll at the end of the film makes you realize who owns the movie (if you haven't done it before) , in terms of money at least.If you have read the book, you will feel a bit out-of-place, because this is not the story you have read. This is a boring story, with characters that make no sense, and scenes that make less sense. If you haven't read the book, you will mostly likely want not to create a wrinkle in time, but in space. More specifically to your sofa. A wrinkle to your sofa.#AWrinkleInTime becomes a #AWasteOfTime

Yes, there are a few great performances and the core story is worth watching, but there are too many problems surrounding that element to really send anyone out to see this in theatres. This is a neat and complex idea that would've worked as a much grander and elongated epic. Ava Duvernay is a fantastic director that tried a little too hard to impress here and I truly hate to have to admit that about this promising storyline. Overall, this is a pretty middle-of-the-road picture.

reviews.review_title: Watch the trailer, then watch what's next on your list
reviews.content: Let me start off by saying this is one of those movies with a great trailer but fails to deliver come showtime. You are free to leave while you still can because it's gonna get ugly from here on out.Based on the science fantasy novel of the same name released in 1962, it follows the story of Meg who aided by three mythical beings go on a quest to find her missing father. Classic plot enough to bring in the dollar for Disney, right? On top of that, you got a great cast featuring Reese Witherspoon, Chris Pine and even Michael Pena but just the same they weren't enough to save the movie from "tessering" to disaster territory.First the positives: Chris Pine was able to give great acting even though he was given barely anything to work with. I once outrightly dismissed him after seeing him in 'Just My Luck', back in 2006 when Lindsay Lohan was still a thing. He's steadily improved since, between 'This Means War', 'Wonder Woman' and now this. Also worth mentioning is 8yr old Fil-American Deric McCabe who played Charles Wallace. Yes there were some annoying moments (such as the confrontation in the white room) but he showed acting potential and we should see more of him in the future.Now the negatives: The story had so many loopholes and you would know this because you'd wonder about something and even though the cast is just standing there talking no one is explaining it to you. Editing was poorly done and if I had to take a guess I would surmise it's because there weren't a lot of good takes to work with. Even the soundtrack didn't work. I mean I love Sade but the song they chose did not give the feels for the scene they used it for.Lastly the so-sos: Oprah was Oprah, Reese was also Reese and I'm kinda mixed about her performance, like I'm seeing a preview of what to expect in Legally Blonde 4. Mindy, again was the token diversity actress, but that's a progress, from African-Americans we're moving to Asians. In addition, the family in the book was changed from Caucasian to Multiracial in the movie, and I also read somewhere that the book's Christian undertones were heavily edited and they used neutral terms such as light and darkness. While being inclusive opens up more opportunities for everyone, it feels like they spent too much time focusing on that instead of the story therefore it felt forced rather than letting it happen naturally.I'd like to say that this is your usual Disney movie and go watch with your kids, but honestly just watch the trailer and proceed to the next movie on your list.

reviews.review_title: A well-intentioned mess that manages to be weird - and yet also not weird enough.
reviews.content: Since its publication in 1962, Madeleine L'Engle's A Wrinkle In Time has gained a reputation for being unfilmable... for good reason. The book mixes science fiction and Christian theology in an epic odyssey across time, space and the universe - in ways that are endlessly charming to fans, and frustratingly messy to detractors. L'Engle's defiantly episodic tale provides as many pitfalls as opportunities for aspiring filmmakers - accordingly, director Ava DuVernay winds up getting about as much right as she gets wrong.Meg Murry (Storm Reid) - full of youth, self-loathing and abandonment issues - is the prickly heart of the film. It's been four years since her physicist dad (Chris Pine) disappeared, and Meg is still falling apart. But everything changes when her precocious six-year-old brother, Charles Wallace (Deric McCabe), invites a most peculiar stranger into their home. Before long, Mrs Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon) and her two equally unusual friends, Mrs Who (Mindy Kaling) and Mrs Which (Oprah Winfrey), invite the Murry siblings and their new friend, Calvin (Levi Miller), on a journey that will take them to the darkest corners of the galaxy - which might well include the very depths of their own souls.In narrative terms, A Wrinkle In Time makes the canny decision to focus firmly on Meg in moving the story forward. While Meg was also the primary protagonist in the book, L'Engle spent almost as much time dwelling on what made her two male companions so special. The film chooses to lavish more attention on Meg, allowing her and all her insecurities and contradictions to anchor the entire adventure. It's Meg whose undying devotion to her father knocks the travellers off-course, and Meg who refuses to give up when loss threatens to claim her loved ones.On this count, at least, the final result is something quite lovely. Meg is achingly real - an awkward young girl who can neither take nor believe compliments about herself, but who has the potential to change the world if only she can find her confidence and voice. Reid is fantastic in the part, credibly convincing audiences that Meg's faults might also be her gifts - that the outsized amount of love in her heart is not something she needs to hide or play down. It's an empowering message for girls and boys, and probably the best thing about DuVernay's otherwise uneven adaptation.Unfortunately, the rest of A Wrinkle In Time lingers somewhere in the key of mediocre. For a book like L'Engle's, every choice made in changing or updating the novel for the screen will invariably invite debate. Viewers and readers will be discussing for years to come whether Meg's perfectly ordinary twin brothers should have been cut out of the family, and if the film's glamorous, purely Hollywoodian depiction of the three mysterious Mrses somehow makes them less - rather than more - interesting.Where it really counts, however, Jennifer Lee's screenplay seems determined to avoid as much controversy as possible. The film steers almost entirely clear of what made the book such a seminal work of children's literature, paring away the Christian themes and allegories L'Engle embedded in her story and characters. And yet, it retains a lot of the more peculiar detours taken by the book, from visiting a Happy Medium (Zach Galifianakis) to encountering a sinister man with red eyes (Michael Pena). As a result, A Wrinkle In Time is almost as random and weird as the book on which it's based - but lacks the layers and soul that help make the weirdness work.To be fair, there are plenty of enjoyable moments threaded throughout DuVernay's film. If you accept it for what it is, Meg's hero journey is irresistible and important for generations of young girls who will see themselves in her as she steps up and takes charge. Some of the modern updates are hugely welcome - from the diversity of the characters to a quite wonderful Hamilton reference. The cast, too, is uniformly appealing. Witherspoon, in particular, is having the time of her life as the chirpy, chatty Mrs Whatsit;, while Chris Pine continues his streak of playing white, male characters that we don't often see on screen by injecting his performance with a dark fragility.Nonetheless, it's hard to shake the feeling that A Wrinkle In Time could have been so much more. In the hands of DuVernay (and, of course, Disney), the film is visually arresting, turning up the gloss, colour saturation and special effects to elicit full eye-popping wonder. But all the visual resplendence in the world can't disguise the messiness of the film's central themes and ideas. In effect, DuVernay's adaptation - a blockbuster that comes across as safe and generic when it should be bold and unusual - has things of its own to say but, in so doing, it largely misses L'Engle's point.

reviews.review_title: Extremely disappointing considering what they could have done with the story
reviews.content: I saw A Wrinkle in Time today. The first half hour or so had potential, as the little brother was set up as an articulate champion of justice type who dressed down two teachers for spreading malicious gossip about him and his family, and then supported his sister. All this while apparently marshaling the powers that be of the universe to help find their missing father. The sister started out with some potential too, beating up a particularly vicious bully and walking out on a principal who was trying to tear her down without getting the whole story behind her actions first. The acting and makeup for the 3 universe goddess ladies was rather off-putting and honestly came off as TV movie quality, but the CGI once they crossed over to a new place was impressive. Unfortunately, the whole movie falls flat on its face immediately after that and never recovers. Leaving the heavy-handed and insufficiently heartfelt scene with the seer out, the little brother disappears briefly without explanation (only to reappear later also without explanation) during which time the kids run through a supernatural natural disaster of sorts and escape in a barely believable (even in the context of fantasy) way. Shortly after the little brother reappears, he touches the hand of one baddie and suddenly turns into a power-mad villain, which makes no sense since he showed no signs of avarice up to that point and not a drop of darkness in his personality to be used in turning him. If anything, the setup made him seem more likely to end up the hero of the story. This is just clumsy writing. When they finally find the father, despite the fact he's been trapped in the core of evil for the whole universe for 4 years, he shows no signs of having changed in any way - plus he was way too easy to find but that's another issue. Then, even though he's supposed to have been trapped there, he just decides to teleport him and his daughter back home at will. What!?! Couldn't he have done that, say 4 years earlier if it was that simple!?! Also, when he teleports away and the daughter wills herself to stay to go after her brother, the boyfriend is nowhere near and in the end the daughter and her brother go home without the boyfriend... and yet he's there when they arrive home... with no explanation whatsoever. Oh, and one more plot hole regarding the boyfriend. The little brother asked him to come along because they needed his sense of diplomacy, but he never used it once. He barely even spoke. Both he and the little brother had considerable potential as characters, but were not really used at all. What a waste. Finally, the climax "battle" scene of the film kind of undermined the moral of the story (that you should like yourself the way you are) since the argument the daughter made to un-evil her brother was that they loved each other and therefore he couldn't be evil. Huh?Oh, one last note. There was one little moment when the bother yelled to the sister "Shut up, Meg!" Surely someone working on that movie must have seen the show Family Guy once in their life and realized that line would have all the wrong pop culture connotations for a moderately large portion of the audience? I mean, seriously, I don't watch that show and even I know that catchphrase. There was a lot of laughter in the theater at that moment, and I think that's why.I'm guessing something important in the original written story was excised from the screenplay to fill it so full of holes. If not, then this is just a very disappointing story all around. Thematically and stylistically, it wants to be Neverending Story, but it just isn't. At all. Not even close.

reviews.review_title: Inception meets Interstellar, meets Oz the Great and Powerful... confused? You will be!
reviews.content:
As a 40 year old white 'dude'- I was told by Brie Larson that she was NOT interested in my review on this movie, as it- "was not made for me!"
But after watching it... I'm not sure the audience, or the writers, or the cast completely knows who it is for either?
To describe it in a nutshell- 'Inception meets Interstellar, meets Oz the Great and Powerful' (and I didn't really like all three of them)... for kids?... or possibly just girls?... actually it will leave almost EVERYONE confused.
Oprah, Reese Witherspoon and Mandy Kalin seemed awkward, uncomfortable and were all too big and too distinguishable to be in such trippy weird roles.
If the writer/film maker was going for female empowerment, it just wasn't there, though the little girl, boy next door and her brother did pretty good jobs with what they had.
Michael Pena was good, (but brief), he almost always is.
Chris Pine was fine. He always is... never good, always 'just' OK... sigh.
The fantasy world/science talk/space-time left a lot to be desired, and there are elements of hell imagery and evil towards the end that didn't fit with most of the movie.
But all in all, I watched the whole thing to see what would happen next and it was not as bad as the other 2 movies I watched this weekend (Oceans 8 & Halloween 2018) which were both terrible attempts at far left-wing feminist propaganda, which this movie fortunately never really felt like (but it also didn't really feel like a Disney Classic).

reviews.review_title: Had to rate it, and lowest I could do was 1.
reviews.content: More often than not, the genres Adventure, Family, Fantasy has become synonymous with moral studies classes for children about good vs evil. Gone are the days when one could simply sit back and enjoy children's films like the Swiss Family Robinson or Tom Sawyer without being treated to either a contrasting and convoluted twist or a moral science class.

How could they abuse, torture, annihilite one of my absolute favorite books from my childhood? I feel so angry at the director! I think there needs to be a court for punishing these crimes.
Apart from the characters and the premise of the story the movie has nothing - absolutely nothing to do with the book! 
For example Mrs. Whatsit:
Book: "...was it a tramp? It seemed small for Meg's idea of a tramp.The age or sex was impossible to tell, for it was completely bundled up in clothes. Several scarves of assorted colours were tied about the head, and a man's fel hat perched atop. A shocking pink stole was knotted about a rough overcoat, and black rubber boots covered the feet."
In the movie you get a glamorous woman in technicolor dreamcoat clothes who always smiles and has nothing meaninful to contribute to the story.
And why was there a flying lettuce? And how did the smoke monster from Lost make it into the story? Oh, sorry there is no story. That was somehow edited out of the movie. What is left are random fantasy action scenes and long meaningful glances combined with saccharine smiles.

I don't understand the critics' hate on this. I really enjoyed this movie. Almost all the acting was good, the effects were as trippy as they should have been, and the story was more-or-less the same as the book. My only complaints are that the actor who played Charles Wallace was not as creepy in the second half as he should have been. (But he's still a child, so I'm not going to be too harsh). I was worried when Michael Pena was cast as the villain, because generally his roles are comedic, and even when he's playing a villain, like in ''My Little Pony: The Movie" it's as the main villains' sidekick/comic relief. Surprisingly, he did a good job. The character in the story is supposed to be an allegory for the devil, and while he wasn't as creepy as I would have liked, he did add another element to the character by posing as friendly in order to tempt the main characters more. They also got rid of the part of the story with Aunt Beast. (Yay! Seriously. What were those things? Chewbacca's second cousins? Whatever they were, I always hated that part as I felt it slowed the plot down and added nothing. By cutting that part they proved how unnecessary it was and the story still works without it.) Being a Disney film, they of course toned down the creepiness of the planet Camazotz. (Boo!) I would have preferred it to be as scary as the book and 2003 film. It was still a bit unsettling, but not as much as it should have been. Overall, I thought this was a fine adaptation, albeit a slightly flawed one.
Grade: A- 9/10 3.5/5 stars

So much CGI and green screen..it's a pity.. there are like a lot of beautiful places here in the world.. The camera is like inches away from the actors..I thought it were my glasses. Also what up with those dramatic clothing/wigs from the so called misses? It was so weird... Also all that green didn't make Reese Witherspoon prettier or something. So I didn't go into this one with particularly high hopes... lets be honest, Oprah isn't exactly known for her acting skills across her entire career, but I had some hope with Chris Pine and Reese Witherspoon.I've not read the book/s, so I really was going into this blind. I wish at the end of that 1hr40min disaster I'd not only been blind, but also deaf and rather stupid.From start to end, it just lacks any depth, any story, any satisfaction at all other than the occasional bit of great special effects work. The timeline is all over the place, the characters are shallow and lacking any depth that gives you an investment in who they are or what they are doing, and the acting is at best little better than what I would expect of C grade actors. I think Chris and Reese just turned up for a day or two in-between another more interesting and better paid project, meanwhile Oprah just didn't have much else on that month.I really did ponder if I had fallen asleep and missed a main part of the story, but no, I evidently didn't and what seems to be some large jumps in storytelling were indeed what this film had.Maybe it's a kids film, and they might be too daft to notice all the holes and flaws in general, but these days I doubt that. Basically it was just a terrible film, made no worse perhaps by Oprah and her 'acting', but certainly made no better by the supposedly good actors involved.What I find most marvellous is the fact Disney and others continue to no doubt spend millions on this sort of garbage, when that money might be better spent else where, or donated to the poor and homeless. And whoever wrote this script (adapted it from the book I suppose), should be marched immediately out of the office and banished into the nothing. (Speaking of nothing, haven't we heard this concept before, it was far much like 'the never ending story' without the story and the acting and such. I imagine this won't be a movie people will be hunting out 20 years from now as is the case with my generation and the aforementioned Never Ending Story.Certainly don't bother seeing this anywhere that you would have to pay for it, you'll be bored to tears and annoyed you didn't spend your time and money better.

reviews.review_title: Uneven storytelling is buried through the visuals to being a forgettable film.
reviews.content: A Wrinkle in Time (3 out of 5 stars). A Wrinkle in Time a fantasy adventure film that is visually beautiful and stunning to look at if you can get by with a plot that seems hallow. I never read the book; I am coming from a fresh perspective on this film. And it is not Disney's worse film like Tomorrowland. The performances were emotional and inspirational. The visual effects were great. But the plot seems thin when you think about it after it is over. It is one of those films that you see once and may not enjoy the experience again. The plot follows Meg (Storm Reid) after years with the disappearance of her father Dr. Alex (Chris Pine). When he was working on something new that can transport a person between space and time to another universe. Meg's younger adoptive brother Charles Wallace (Deric McCabe) is a genius and has been speaking to Mrs. Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon). Mrs. Whatsit tries to recruit Meg, Charles, and her friend Calvin (Levi Miller) to go on a journey to another planet to search for her missing father. What worked great with A Wrinkle in Time? The film's visual effects were spectacular. Meg meets the three ladies Mrs. Who (Mindy Kaling), Mrs. Which (Oprah Winfrey), and Mrs. Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon) and they go to a beautiful planet, were the flowers speak to each other. They fly through a sky from a mystical transformed creature. Then, they travel to a rocky balanced setting, were they meet Zach Galifianakis's character. Then, to a dark place called the it, were all the dark negative energy lies upon. It is a fun adventure to see these beautiful visual effects. Which is also the weakness of this film as well. When the film relies on visuals over storytelling. Storm Reid did perfect with her performance. You grow to like her character. Levi Miller was also okay as well that has an attraction to Meg. Chris Pine was good as her father for the brief moments that he is on screen. Reese Witherspoon and Mindy Kaling were great as well. What did not work with A Wrinkle in Time? Like I said above, the film relying on visuals over storytelling. The movie is all visual effects and there may be scenes were it is overdone. But the plot is thin. It is about a father's passion in discovering new planets in different universes. And the voyage to the unknown. When Meg goes traveling to one visual fest set piece to another. Meeting new characters and getting a lead to another new setting. There is not much of a story when characters are just traveling to another eye candy visual set piece. There is a theme of love in the film. But does poorly on trying to execute a story. Also, I feel like Oprah Winfrey, Deric McCabe, and Michael Pena's performances were just dull. Winfrey as Mrs. Which did not have any depth with the character. Deric McCabe did decent as a genius kid. Michael Pena as Red was just terrible.Overall, A Wrinkle in Time is a fair film. The visual effects are spectacular but overwhelming. The plot is thin and forgettable. Storm Reid was great and some decent performances from the supporting cast. Otherwise, I will recommend the film as a rental unless you are a fan of the book or want to see some stunning visuals on the big screen.
The most boring movie I have seen. What a disappointment.

reviews.review_title: This is why we need a zero-star option.
reviews.content: I gave it two stars, so that my rating won't be lost in the intricate vote-average system, which ignores 1's and 10's.Anyway, from the way this movie was hyped and promoted constantly on Ellen and other talk shows, I knew it would be bad. But it exceeded my expectations... meaning that I didn't expect it to be this awful.You wouldn't believe it, I certainly wouldn't believe it either if someone told me... but these people spent 100-million dollars for a movie with no sets at all (everything is low grade CGI). But the most significant, inconceivable point is that the plot involves children going to a magical land where everything is magical, and you know, filled with magic and stuff that has magic in it... with the added bonus of magic. You know? Flying creatures, beautiful landscape, which is supposed to make the kids in the audience "woooow!" like their onscreen counterparts, and carry them away for two hours.Which could very well happen, of course. But only if the kids in the audience haven't seen any of the eight Harry Potter films. Or the Narnia films. Or the Lord Of The Rings films. Or Spiderwick. Or Labyrinth. Or any of the dime-a-dozen, you-get-free-with-any-10-dollar-purchase children's animation DVDs. Or any of the stuff that's free on TV (which are all way better than this).I know for a fact that it's playing on a non-stop loop on the world's largest, diamond-studded TV somewhere in Oprah's palace, just to give her a chance to see herself some more, but if you've seen any movie that's been made in the last 20 years... hell, even if you've seen any well-made commercial, you can skip this one.

reviews.review_title: TOO much taken out of the book
reviews.content: First off, I know books turned into movies will always be different. However, this is the first one I saw where so much was eliminated that the movie just does not makes sense. Most of what I loved about the book was the journey Meg took to get to her father and all the events that happen along the way. This movie basically glossed right over those, which took out so much of the joy of the story. I went with someone who never read the book and she was so confused over this entire movie's concept, basically because the entire middle of the story-line was missing. I was really looking forward to this movie because this was one of my top five books growing up. It's so sad that the transition was done so poorly.

All the cast and crew wasted their talent on a script that's not even very faithful to the book and a director, whom I blame for some of the poor acting on its actors. I think the actors would actually do a very good job if it wasn't for the director, they all have potential but unfortunately, they wasted their talents on poor directing and writing.The cast is miscast. Something about Storm Reid just didn't feel like Meg to me, she did pretty well portraying her insecure personality but she just seemed robotic when Meg was much more of an emotional character in the book. I guess it's because adapting a book character as emotional as Meg would make the movie too dramatic but when strange things would be happening, she would be like "Oh okay..." she didn't show much expressions of curiosity, fear, confusion etc.. Mrs. Whatsit played by Reese Witherspoon just seemed too excitable. Also, Reese Witherspoon is like in her 40s while I saw Mrs. Whatsit as an older woman. Mrs. Who, played by Mindy Kaling would mostly talk in quotes and would even say things that didn't feel natural to the scenes. Charles Wallace is supposed to be 5 yet Deric McCabe looks like he's 9. And Calvin has the cliched love-at-first-sight thing going on, swooning over Meg's hair and how she's hot.The only good things I can say about the movie were the visuals and most of the more fast-paced scenes. They were fun to watch. But all in all, this is an unfaithful adaptation of a book that takes out some important parts from the book and adds some new ones.I do believe "A Wrinkle in Time" book has the potential to get adapted to a good film, maybe not an excellent film because the book is too complex to be made into a wonderful film.

reviews.review_title: All the hype was only in the Trailer
reviews.content: Sigh... I went in with high expectation as seeing a number of big names in Hollywood (it Oprah for goodness sake!) But much to my disappointment the big names remained just big names. Oprah, Mindy Kaling and Reese Witherspoon who played Mrs. Which, Mrs. Whatsit and Mrs. Who have little to no significant roles in this movie. I kept waiting to see more magical moments coming from these three roles but only met with the lack of it. This movie missed numerous opportunities to deliver some comedic moment/line either from the three misses or the children. Talking bout the children, yeah they're cute and pretty all that but there's nothing really making them quite likeable especially the main child, Meg. She's described as unorganised, problematic, aggressive kid but all of these characteristics were only proven in the movie in 1 scene only and what, they thought that is enough to make us believe that she is this out of control, problematic girl?? Heck no. As mentioned, there is nothing really likeable or relatable with the character Meg and so its hard to care for her and in the end, I just can't help but to not rooting for her. She is in this magical journey with her lil bro and friend but all she keep doing was complaining, but at the same wanting to save her father. How the heck do you wanna save your father when all you do is complain? reviews.content: I didn't believe the reviews and thought it couldn't be, it's a Disney film. WRONG. Boring beyond belief. The casts seems forced. I'm a minority, but sorry I didn't appreciate the diversity at all. Boyfriend fell asleep 3 times and never finish. I finished in 2 sittings. There's nothing to see here. Don't waste your time. After 10-15 minutes in the movie, I started thinking what have i gotten myself into and why why why didn't I read the reviews before I watched it? Life is full of regrets and these are moments I'll NEVER ever get back again my life. Meg, her face is frozen in sourness from start to finish, even after finding dad and that final hug, her face is still stuck in a dour expression. Smiling takes a lot of effort out of her and seemed even unnatural. Perhaps she should have played the role of one of the mean kids?Charles Wallace, For heaven's sake must you call him with both names ALL the time!!!!??? And the looks they gave each other is so awkward.Plot is non existent, tries too hard to push a lesson that no one cares about. I heard about how bad this movie was, but I wanted to give it a try and see for myself. I managed 45 minutes and turned it off.I remember at the Oscars when they gate crashed a screening of it during the show, this probably stopped people from walking out of the screening as it couldn't have been the movie keeping them in their seats.The acting was that of a bad stage play, like they just didn't really care and probably did one take and thought "that'll do".

I enjoy a good family movie, but this is just not good. I liked some of the science elements to it, but that isn't what this movie focused on.Plenty of better family sci-fi movies out there;
The Last Mimzy, Flight of the Navigator, Explorers, Titan A.E. to name a few
Kids were bored, I was bored. No cohesiveness. Story made no sense and was all over the place. How did this get released?

reviews.review_title: Bruh.... The Things We Do for Love Right?
reviews.content: Look.... This movie was so bad that I made an active choice to make a log in account just to leave this review. I have to die knowing that a small chunk of my brain will remember the disappointment I have for two things - this movie and myself for not having the balls to tell my spouse "NO!"........

This movie doesn't receive all it's props. I believe many don't have the right amount of imagination to watch this movie which is why everyone else is reviewing and giving it a 1. This movie was well put together and captured many parts from the book. To have adults and kids intrigued by the same movie, I believe its a win!

I literally made an account on this site so I could redirect the negative attitude towards this movie. Granted I have never read the book, but this movie made me want to. I don't care if it doesn't do justice to the novel, we can not overlook the overlying message this movie tries to portray to its viewers. It is a beautiful work of art on its own, visually, and through story-telling. It is all about the conquering of our own insecurities and faults through the power of love, a force so strong it bends space and time. Shame on anyone who discredits this movie due to its discontinuities to its source material. This movie is a verdict of how we should be living and treating others, and to deny its quality is bringing the darkness out into this world. It's a beautiful movie, touching, and very teaching. Please watch it and take it whole heartedly. It's absolutely gorgeous.
I had hoped this would be a fun, maybe thought provoking movie. I was wrong!!! Upside down plot with weak characters and progressive politics thrown in for good measure....

reviews.review_title: "Disappointing" is too much of an understatement
