I felt my money and time wasted and even watching it in 3D did not make it a special one!

reviews.review_title: Best adaptation yet, amazing visuals, good movie
reviews.content:
First and foremost, this is a very good movie. What it is not is a direct retelling of the story. It's a story about family, love, and self empowerment with parts of the original story woven throughout. If you can keep that in mind as you watch this movie, I think you'll enjoy it. I did.
It's been a long time since I read the books, but I read all of them (and the related Austins books). As such, I can't remember more than a few scenes from the book, let alone the specific details. But there was enough of the original story "enfolded" within the movie that it feels close enough to be easily recognizable.
Is it a "perfect" movie? No. But it's the best adaptation of the books that I've seen yet. Very well done.
And the beautiful visuals are stunning. The acting is (generally) good to great (some of the supporting characters are too one dimensional to be really believable, but they are really only there to serve as instantly recognizable stereotypes anyway). But the leads all mail it.
The thing you have to understand is that this movie is loosely based on the book, but it's also it's own story, and it does as very good job telling that story. It's a story about how important love is in a world where hatred, picture perfect consumerism, and general nastiness runs rampant. Maybe if we take the movie's lesson to heart, we won't have to travel to the ends of the universe to figure it out.
If you're looking for a positive, visually glorious, slightly perilous (it made my youngest grab for my hand in a few places), and thoroughly entertaining escape for 110 minutes, then this might be a good movie for your to watch.
But, if all you want to do is compare it to the book or bash on Oprah, then you won't enjoy this and you'll leave toxic reviews like so many other people have done. People who chose to spread darkness instead of celebrating a movie that strives to bring light, good lessons, and fun to the world.

reviews.review_title: Geez. Calm down people. It was fine.
reviews.content: Just watched this with my class of 30 eleven and twelve year-olds after studying the book. They actually enjoyed the movie more than the book, although they were disappointed when a couple of key moments were left out. The acting by the young cast was fantastic, especially Storm Reid. The music is beautiful. There were a few spine tingling moments and some of my students shed a tear or two. I think it really helps to have read the book and if you haven't read it recently, you might find it's not as great as you remembered. It's a movie for kids. They gave it a 7 out of ten. I give it a six.

reviews.review_title: A nice slow paced children's movie
reviews.content: The movie is nice and sweet. It's very slow and simple. It's a children's movie for ages until 10 years.

reviews.review_title: I tried to have an open mind
reviews.content:
I went into this movie expecting to be frustrated and disappointed, but hoping to be wrong. I was frustrated and disappointed, but there were a few bright spots.Bright spots:The way Meg approached her father at the end was much more interesting than in the book. The eerie disturbingness of the bouncing-ball children was conveyed better in the movie than in the bookThe last tesseract was beautiful and cathartic.
Disappointments:There was not enough contrast between Charles Wallace and IT/Charles Wallace. It was like the difference between a 5yo in a good mood and a tired, cranky 5yo, not the difference between a loving but young genius and a child whose mind has been taken over by a planet-destroying source of evil.Dr. Mother Murray was written/acted as worried and scared most of the time. In the book she was so unflappable that her calm was practically science fiction in itself. That's what I wanted to see.Mrs. Whatsit was mean to Meg on more than one occasion. One of my favorite things about the Mrs. Ws is their frumpiness, that manages, for many people, to conceal their brilliant natures. I wish it had been possible to do that in the film. Instead, we had yet another conflation of beauty and goodness. :-(

reviews.review_title: For Abandoned Daughters Who Miss Their Fathers

You'll just regret it.

reviews.review_title: Why did they turn Mrs. Whatsit into a vegetable?
reviews.content: It is SHOCKING how bad this movie is and how different it is from the book. For context, we had to read this book in class, then watch the movie. I heard from another teacher that we were supposed to do a compare and contrast between the movie and the book, so I decided to pull my notebook out and list all the differences. These differences lasted a little more than a page. The contrasts ranged from, "The cast looks different than described in the book." to "Why did they remove and add so many unnecessary scenes?"The only reason why this review isn't 1 star is because visually, the movie is stunning. Not the best ever, but definitely a lot better than other movies I've seen. However, I wish the budget wasn't spent so much on visuals, and spent more on runtime. The movie begins and ends so quickly, so you never really get to know the characters. I didn't care for anybody, because the scenes were going by too fast to comprehend. If this was someone's first exposure to the 'Wrinkle in Time' series, I think they would feel incredibly underwhelmed.

reviews.review_title: Imaginative Adaptation of a Great Book
reviews.content: The novel, A Wrinkle in Time, was the first I read that really felt like "my" book. I was 12 years old, and was totally captivated and changed by the story. I have re-read it numerous times in my life, taking new lessons from it at different stages in my life.I approached the movie with trepidation, especially after the terrible adaptation done in 2003, but I was pleasantly surprised by this well-made film. I thought the movie caught the spirit of the book, while updating it cleverly.The kid actors were terrific, especially Storm Reid as Meg. A couple of the "relevant" jokes (Mrs. Who making hip-hop references) were too cute, but I liked how they linked mean girl culture to self-esteem and then linked that to the spreading darkness of "It." While that is not what L'engle wrote, it is definitely in the spirit of her message.The filmmakers made great use of a smart black girl lead. When "It" tempts her with a life where she's popular, the vision includes her having straightened hair. Making Oprah Winfrey, as Mrs. Which, her mentor also underlined this thread. Again, a brilliant way to make the film relevant to 2018 without losing the heart of the story in any way.The movie really needed another 30 minutes in its run-time (and it wasted 12 of what it had with a stupid sequence of "hey look at me!" CGI), and needed to work a little harder on selling the physics, but I thought it was solid.

After hearing the horrible reviews, I was dreading seeing this film. But I'd promised my kids so away we went! It could have been worse, and I was mildly entertained. I gave it a 6 because it wasn't s bad as a 5, but it isn't quite a 6 either The acting by Storm Reid was weaker than I expected, and the acting by the boy who played Charles Wallace was worse. I have liked Reese Witherspoon in everything I've ever seen her in but her, she is not quirky and adorable the way she's supposed to be (I think?) Mindy Kahling also just floated over her lines without infusing much meaning into them. The boy who played Calvin, and the other adult actors were excellent. Worth seeing on BluRay or if you're really in need of something to do with the kids.

reviews.review_title: At least appreciate the show stealing brilliance of 9 year old Deric Mcabe
reviews.content: The Disney Plus streaming service has introduced me to so many unexpected delights old and new that I would not have otherwise bothered with.This is one such unexpected surprise. In fact, I actually did read the novel a few years ago and I hated the saccharine overly done "love" theme and in your face religious aspects (I do enjoy subtle religious underpinnings in movies that give good morals but not when it's in your face). The book had some standout sequences that are memorable but overall it was not a children's book that I liked. To give you context, I adore children fantasy stories such as Tom's Midnight Garden, Moondial, Narnia series, Harry Potter, Dark Materials, etc.But I do love the promotional images of this film, it looks lavish and at least I thought to watch it just to appreciate the visuals. I am one who never ever watch or read something based on other people's opinions. I will decide for myself and I literally judge a book by its cover.One of the many positive stand outs in this film is the surprisingly nuanced performances of all the child stars. Particularly, 9 year old Deric Mcabe who literally stole the show for perhaps a good quarter of the movie's runtime. What a delicious performance, I hope this young child actor is well taken care of, has a happy childhood and not pushed into a career for the sake of wealth. But as long as he wishes to continue on that path, he will have my attention of high anticipation for greatness. The main star, 14 year old Storm Reid was also impressive with some moments of very heart felt nuances. There is no forced acting that one expects with child actors. The adult stalwarts did their part in their accomplished professional ways.But the film itself turned out to be a lovely visual journey with some heartfelt moments of psychological drama and surreal weirdness (something I wish it had delve into further)It has it's plentiful flaws for sure but seeing all those one star ratings is just utter madness. One of those flaws is a certain obvious godliness of Oprah Winfrey's presence that seems a bit unnecessary. I like Oprah, I just don't think it was really needed for her to be so godly! Being the leader would have sufficed.Another criticism I would have is that this could have done with much more humour. Reese Witherspoon's character has some comic relief moments but..just didn't feel enough.What I really appreciated is that unlike the book, this film gives a satisfying complete story. The book had sequels to complete it's main storyline. But as with all movie adaptations, much is cut out and I do feel the stripping down of some of the novel makes the flow of the film rather too haphazard.But the film works for me. It has some memorable sequences and is not anywhere as saccharine as I feared it would be. The journey is disjointed but the performances, visual imagination, Deric Mcabe's show stealing sequence and overall storyline makes up for the shortcomings.I give this a very worthy 7/10.

It was confusing, had too fast of a pace (felt like they were trying to squeeze two books into 1 movie), felt really dark for a Disney movie, and was way off from the book. I thought it was more like Disney was showing off their visual effects, rather than a story. Nothing special, just okay.

A flying lettuce, love makes interstellar travel possible, the darkest mind in the universe is a black cave of synapses, and they walk through ripples of love portals.. Decent soundtrack, a few nice moments of cinematography and color. Glad Netflix picked this up, glad I didn't pay to see it in the theater.

reviews.review_title: A movie that captured a moment in time
reviews.content: Wow! How do you put this classic book into the big screen? Through the eyes of Ava DuVernay, that's how. The story was weaved together so well that I was transported into a book I've read many times. It was brilliantly brought into the modern day with subtlety that is rarely seen. More than the graphic work, acting and visual effects was the under lying message that met my family head on as Meg's emotional journey mirrored my youngest daughter current struggles. It led to "aha" moments and a different perspective.I will watch this movie again and again!

This movie was awful. It wasn't the acting it was the storyline. All regerences to Christianity were removed and it ruined the entire film. One more example of Holllywoods warped reasoning. I would NOT recommend this film unless you like throwing your money away

I see a lot of reviewers here have read the book that this movie was loosely adapted from Well, coming from someone who HASN'T read the book. Maybe this review might be helpful to others out there who are like me:Plot: 3.5/10
Cinematography: 4/10
Visuals: 7/10
Actors: 7/10
Overall: 3/10I watched the movie almost nearly blindfolded. All I checked out was the cast and the plot summary. The pace of the movie felt slow. The actors were great on their own (except Calvin which I'll explain later), as well as the visuals but the plot was too cliche and predictable ... which made the movie an overall "bore" to watch. 
But it wasn't that boring though, given a lil thanks to the visuals. That's how I felt anyway, otherwise I would have yawn multiples times throughout the movie; but I didn't.Anyway, good acting came from the star actors, especially lil Charles Wallace (played by Deric McCabe). But one main character felt a bit odd to watch and that is Calvin (played by Levi Miller). Dude looks and sounds like he's high/drugged on some love spell. And I'm not sure if that's intentional or not but I did not feel any emotional depth in character. Like he's just there for the sake of being there. And the plot... ayy, nothing much to say about it other than it being absolutely predictable. Especially with the whole "there is light in darkness" concept. So yes, just like most of the folks here have said: "very poor script". 
And it's such a shame really because I felt there IS potential to bring out that hidden awesomeness in it---I wondered why the advertising for this movie was not that happening. Well, that's a good thing I guess because if it were then the hit from critics would be a lil more painful.

This mess is as bad a adaptation of a novel as I've seen. I read the book several times as a kid, loved it and was really looking forward to the movie. I hadn't watched any trailers or read any reviews, so I was going into this with an open mind.My heart sank as soon as I heard the godawful bubble-gum 'music' and I realised straight away that this was going to be another pile of manure, concocted to appeal to as many social demographics as possible.The young cast, especially the kid who played Meg, a complex (and interesting) character in the book, are terrible, the adult cast even worse.I can't bring myself to write any more, because that would involve me having recall memories of the time I wasted watching this complete and utter annihilation of a classic.Avoid.

I don't understand the negative reviews. People giving this film 1 star have to be dealing with their own issues and prejudices.I'm a 30 year old man, and this film really touched my soul. It wasn't! There were some dazzling visuals in this film, and the soundtrack and music choices complimented every bit of the film perfectly.This cast was amazing, and the acting of the main actress was phenomenal!Thrilled to say that I will be watching anything Ava DuVernay puts her name on. She did a stunning job, and I will from this day on think of her as a visionary. Because she is!Just remember that this is a children's movie based on a children's book. If you enjoyed the book, there's no reason you can't enjoy this film.If you don't like this film, the film isn't the problem. Your eyes are the problem.

I didn't go to see A Wrinkle in Time at the theater after reading so many poor reviews. This was one of my favorite books as a child so I didn't want to see my love for it ruined by some poor attempt to bring it to the screen. It's been so long since I read it that I don't remember every detail, but the impressions and fondness have remained for decades. So, I finally decided to watch it on Netflix. Some of the poor reviews were from reader's of the book, that's why I can't understand so many bad ones. No, it's not completely faithful (at least as far as I remember), but the impressions, images, and feelings are recalled in this movie. It brought me back to things I read, visualized, and imagined. It reproduced the facination I got from reading the book, if not totally, enough to be worth it for me.Can a movie match a book when that book creates images and feelings that last nearly 5 decades? Maybe not quite, maybe not completely, maybe not with as much power. But I liked this movie and I am very happy to have an old love recalled in a way that brings back even some of that original fascination. I wish I'd seen it on the big screen.

reviews.review_title: A bloated and tone deaf adaptation
reviews.content: Madeline L'Engle, author of A Wrinkle in time was asked about the first filmic iteration of her novel, a 2003 made for tv movie. She said she knew it was going to be bad- and that it was. If Madeline were with us today, I'd be willing to bet she'd really dislike this terrible new version of her fantasy. There are a number of reasons for the truly awful viewing experience this film turns out to be, prime among them the fatal miscasting of almost every character in the book. This is especially true of Charles Wallace and Meg, the main protagonists of the story. Important scenes from the book have been omitted and the film's leaden pacing all but obliterates the suspense that made the novel so memorable. What really sinks A Wrinkle in Time is the fact that the book's sense of wonder, it's raison d'etre, if you will, is missing. Instead, we're subjected to overblown special effects sequences, stunt casting and bad acting. The irony is that the 2003 film that Madeline disliked comes closer to the heart of her story than this stinker.

reviews.review_title: A Wrinkle in Time Review : Good Movie - 7/10
reviews.content: "A Wrinkle in Time" in general is a good movie. It portrayed amazing visuals. And as far as the story is, it was good! One of the some of little problems from the movie was the acting and character development. Although you get development, you don't really care about the characters until later in the movie. The spirits didn't really explain themselves until the middle of the movie. Calvin doesn't get explained a whole lot. And the explanation of how and why Charles Wallas came in contact with Mrs. Whatsit, Mrs. Who, and Mrs. Which is never really explained. Now as far as acting goes, Oprah Winfrey (Mrs. Which) Reese Witherspoon (Mrs. Whatsit) and Mindy Kaling (Mrs. Who) did fantastic. Storm Reid (Meg), Deric McCabe (Charles Wallas), and Chris Pine (Mr. Murray) also did a great job. Levi Miller (Calvin) also did good but didn't express emotion into his character. Overall the acting was great.All in all, this was a good adaptation of a wonderful book. They already made an adaptation prior to this one in 2003. 7/10 Good Movie :)

reviews.review_title: A Wrinkle in Time? More Like A Waste Of Time!
reviews.content:
Going into the theater I was with my seventh grade sister and my boyfriend. We were just finding a way to pass the time by going to the movies and to just hang out because what else do you really do on a Sunday night in the winter. I'm not very critical of movies or actors, I like most films I see even if they are a bit cheesy/cringe worthy and I never really knew what "bad acting" looked like, so walking into this I was expecting a mediocre film. I heard good things about the book that was published in 1962, lots of people said it was a classic that everyone adored. The casting also raised the stakes a bit considering Oprah Winfrey, Reese Witherspoon, Mindy Kaling and, one of my favorite actors, Zach Galifianakis were in it. They were also the face of all of the commercials shown for this science fiction film. The first fifteen minutes I was thinking to myself, "This isn't very good so far, but I'm going to give it some time, I'm sure it will get better!" Boy was I wrong. The acting and plot may have been some of the worst I have ever seen. Let me take this apart step by step. 
 Let's start with the plot. I haven't read the book, but I read a brief synopsis before we went in so that I could have a better understanding. To summarize it, the main character Meg (Storm Reid) and her younger brother Charles Wallace (Deric McCabe) have been left alone with their mother after their scientist father has disappeared for five years. Their father had thought up of a concept called a tesseract. A tesseract is the fifth dimension that can shorten the distances across both time and space therefore, forming a "wrinkle in time", hence the name of the movie. The kids, especially Meg, have been dealing with the absence of their father very poorly, affecting their social life and school work. Out of nowhere, (literally with no reason) Mrs. Whatsit (Reese Witherspoon) shows up and starts talking nonsense about their father and his study. After this incident, the kids get involved with two other mysterious astral travelers (Oprah Winfrey and Mindy Kaling). Now this is where it gets messy; the director did a bad job explaining on what was happening and why. One minute the kids and the travelers would be on another planet, and the next they would encounter an "evil force". To sum it up, the whole movie was these kids looking for their father with these mysterious travelers and !!SPOILER ALERT!! They find him and they all live happily ever after. The transitions between each part of the movie was unclear and confusing. The director did NOT do a good job.
 Now, I don't know much about acting and I haven't really noticed bad acting before but this movie was the definition of bad acting. The main character, Meg, was honestly terrible. I just remember this one line that she said and it made me cringe so much. Reese Witherspoon, Oprah Winfrey and Mindy Kaling weren't bad at acting but it just seemed like they didn't fit in with this type of movie. I view them as serious actors but this movie is like a joke in my eyes. The script was just not good, at all. The actors would say obvious things that just made you go "Really? Are you really that dumb?" I do give the movie some credit for having good actors to star in it to attract attention but that does not mean it was a good movie. 
 The one good thing that I will say about this awful movie is that the special effects were pretty cool. It was interesting and was probably the only thing that kept my attention throughout the movie. The whole concept of this movie was good and it has potential, but the way it was approached was just really terrible. I think after all the reviews this movie has gotten, the producers would do many things differently. So, to sum everything up, this is my least favorite movie I have ever seen and I was VERY disappointed. Definitely a WASTE of time. The only reason why I would tell someone to watch this film is for me to discuss the things that were so bad about it with that person. I wish I could wrinkle that time when I was in the theater.

It was intense, dramatic, and filled with compassion to an extent in which I've never seen in a film. It was beautifully directed, and the actors more than outdid themselves, they were in fact phenomenal and I'm in fact shocked by the reviews that I've seen posted on here. Let me be the first to tell you that they are dead wrong. I don't take films or their artistry lightly, and by no means are the people downing this film correct in any way. This was by far the best movie I have ever seen in my 25 years on this planet. It had me in tears, laughing out loud, angry, anxious, and full of love to the point where it touched my heart to its very core. I believe that everyone who is interested in a well done and an artistically beautiful film needs to see this one. It will stay with me for the rest of my life, and I would see it 1000 times over, just for the sheer joy it brought to me and my loved ones. It is more than worth it, and you'll walk away from it feeling better than when you'd walked in. Prepare yourself for an amazing ride, and enjoy!

"A Wrinkle in Time" is a baffling movie experience. It's an ambitious adaptation, and I'll give them credit for trying, but they come nowhere close to pulling it off. The story is a complete mess. There's no rhyme or reason to the events that happen, the places they visit, and the people and things they encounter. I'm sure in the book these things were all developed and explained thoroughly but in the movie it all just comes off as random and nonsensical. One moment they're on some planet riding a space wizard, the next moment they go to another planet to visit another space wizard, then suddenly they are in another place facing an inexplicable hazard that of course they magically overcome, then they're at a beach running into a red-eyed Michael Pena, etc. It's science-fiction/fantasy at its worst, where the story is completely incoherent and all the explanations for what's happening is just 'magic' or 'love' or 'because'.The dialogue is also so artificial, that's just not how people talk to each other, at least not in the modern day setting it's supposed to be set in. And 'Charles Wallace' is an incredibly dumb and annoying name. I find it very hard to believe that at least the sister wouldn't have found a shortened nickname to use. That may sound like a minor nitpick, but considering they say/shout the name about a hundred times during the movie, it just becomes grating to the ears.It's a shame, because there's so much talent involved in the making of this movie. The cast is top notch, although many of the actors are wasted on dumb characters, and even all the younger actors do a very good job, particularly the young girl. It has a talented up-and-coming director. Visually it looks pretty great most of the time and it does some really cool and unique things with the visuals, but visuals alone can't save a movie if they serve no purpose to the story. The one area of the movie I do consistently really like is the score, particularly in those moments that are meant to avoke wonder. It's nothing too revolutionairy, just very well-executed, and I was not surprised to learn from the credits that the composer is the excellent Ramin Djawadi of Game of Thrones and Westworld fame.Overall, this adaptation was a sorry misfire that was unfortunately doomed to fail from the start. Complex science fiction and fantasy stories that deal with complicated matters such as different dimensions and time travelling/bending (of which there is a severe lack in a movie that has the concept of 'time' in its title by the way), simple cannot be accurately translated into a 100 minute movie, mainly aimed at children. It usually either becomes an exposition dump of dry information, or they simply don't bother to properly explain the concepts at all, both of which result in poor story-telling. Maybe in the future, these novels get the elongated television series treatment they deserve, similar to how the upcoming His Dark Materials (2019) tv series will hopefully clear the stain of the horrible 'The Golden Compass' (2007) movie adaptation.

Based on the fantasy novel, A Wrinkle in Time follows a girl and her younger brother as they venture through reality to find their father who went missing years ago. Along the way, they come across a slew of creative characters and eye pleasing visuals. And that's about all the film has to offer. A Wrinkle in Time is not only overly whimsical, but also contains moments that are so awful they're almost laughably bad. One of these scenes involves a gigantic Oprah Whinfrey who plays Mrs.Which, gazing down like a diety at the main characters as they whimsically run through an enchanting island, even though their father's life is on the line. The rest of the film is a series of forcefully enchanting moments that don't exactly propel the story. Sometimes the filmmakers even throw in some modern pop music! It only gets cheesier from there. The film's only saving grace lies in the relationship between Chris Pine and Storm Reid. Both of these actors do a good job conveying a father-daughter relationship through acting alone. Keep in mind I said "acting" alone. Toward the end of the film, one of these characters does something very unforgivable that isn't addressed for the remaining of the film. In terms of dramatics storytelling, this ruins the once believable relationship. Aside from some nice visuals, which honestly could have been better considering the film was made under Disney, A Wrinkle in Time is a forgettable and overblown fantasy that is worth skipping over.

reviews.review_title: Confused by reviews - I enjoyed it.

Charles Wallace was not as developed as I would have liked, but knowing the story, that was OK. (One of those missing scenes where Meg confronts her father and all the ways they try to break CW away from the IT should have been in there...)I will admit that would actually give the movie a 7 or so, but I rated it higher because I fear that MANY of the reviews are racially motivated and thereby bringing the overall score down. This makes me very sad, especially considering the theme and point of the book and film.

Saw it on Sunday, opening weekend with my wife and 10yo daughter. This is based on a beloved book, that my mother told me was one of her favorites of all time. We loved it. It was a good movie, that isn't meant for everyone.
I liked it, but my daughter loved it. This movie was made for her. She's gifted, she's got ADHD, she marches to her own drum, and is now at the point in school where she has learned that not everyone wants to be her friend.
She cried happy tears many times. She snuggled into her parents during the movie. That's why I know this movie hit where it was supposed to. 
My mom would have loved it. It had everything she loved about the book.
I'm good with that.

Ava Duvernay has done it again.A Wrinkle in Time is stunning. It's gorgeous, thought provoking and filled with adventure. This movie of course is based off the novel by Madeleine L'Engle. It focuses on the Murray family, namely Meg and her younger brother Charles Wallace. Their father, a famous scientist, has been missing for four year and three mysterious women appear to help the children find him.If you're a person who likes dark, depressing movies, I'm going to go ahead and say skip this movie because one of the main themes about this film is love. It's like the book as well. One of the reasons this film is so great is it shows young girls that love can be a powerful thing. Storm Reid (who plays Meg) does a fantastic job, giving us a character who is relatable and admirable. Deric McCabe (Charles Wallace) also does a fantastic job. The casting in this film is phenomenal, giving us a fantastic cast and each actor delivers a wonderful performance. I honestly think this film did a great job of adapting the source material. I couldn't be happier and I enjoyed this film. If you liked the book, go see this movie. If you haven't read the book, I would say stay away.

When I heard that Ava Duvernay was making an adaptation of one of my favorite books, I was excited; finally, a great filmmaker can do justice to the story after the TV-movie fiasco. Unfortunately, the studios must have tampered with the adaptation as it isn't a movie directed by a talented director; instead, it is more of a nauseous CGI-induced trainwreck being conducted by unusually drunk circus animals.Before I get my numerous gripes with movie out of my system, I'll at least commend it for casting a black girl as Meg Murry. It was a very brave decision, especially considering that it was a major blockbuster coming from the image-obsessed corporate known as Disney.I also want to state upfront that race has nothing to do with me not liking the film. I'm whiter than snow and thus don't get racist crap thrown at me with the same intensity/frequency that some of my fellow citizens sadly do. I accept that everyone is different, but I judge people based on their character, not their physical differences.
This comes from my unique upbringing - I'm autistic and suffer from OCD. I'm extremely sympathetic towards people. I grew up in a multicultural diverse church - Bridgeway Community Church, if you're curious; my father has traveled all over the world and taught me to love all kinds of people for their differences. I'm a social advocate who believes in the Black Lives Matters movement as a stepping stone for much-needed racial conciliation. There's not a racist fragment in my being. I also don't have a vendetta against the director. On the contrary, Ava DuVernay is a great person who has made great contributions to the art of cinema, especially with her wonderful documentary 13th. Rather, I'm just stunned that her latest movie was poorly made studio-processed garbage.The movie's basic composition/mise-en-scene was shockingly most unprofessional; its ugly color schemes made the Transformers movies, aka decomposing roadkill, look attractive by comparison. All the acting performances were horrific, especially with the child actors being the most guilty of making wood look more human. The music comprised of soullessly generic pop hits that it arrived deader than a doornail.Worse of all, the script reeked of corporate pandering. First of all, it censored the book's inherent liberal Christian ideology to the point that it became a name-in-only adaptation. Second, it became a boringly bad-at-motivational cliche fest that not even an innocent child would willingly accept. Third, it got rid of what made the book special, which was making kids think for themselves. Gone with the cool scientific concepts, in with cringeworthy CGI and overblown nonsense that insults basic intelligence.The more I write about this disaster, the more I feel sorry for Ms. DuVernay. She clearly has talent, yet her vision conflicted with the studio's financial priorities; hence, we end up with this cinematic travesty. Worse of all, this movie doesn't work with its prime audience as we don't find the characters relatable like how we do with Madeline L'Engle's timeless book.I watched the movie with my older sister and her two kids- both of whom are in preschool. When the movie ended, my sister was gobsmacked at how awful it was. Her children played with their toys once the movie lost their attention yet they stayed within distance of the dreadful thing. Wanting to know what her children thought of the film, she asked her youngest child if the movie was any good. Barely looking up from his toys, he shook his head and replied with one new vocabulary word: "No".

reviews.review_title: Not great, but also not as terrible as they'd let you think
reviews.content: So let's get the good stuff out there: the visuals are pretty great. I loved the costumes of the Mrses, Nobody, and I dug Zach Galifianakis as Happy Balance. I liked the diversity of the cast, as it didn't seem to make much a difference either way, which is refreshing. I thought much of the cinematography was well done and quite beautiful. Now for the faults: like most people who have seen this film, the plot is severely lacking. I understand that they're going to find Meg's father, but that is clearly the McGuffin here. Though it's role as the McGuffin is largely undercut by the fact that Meg's father's disappearance is supposed to be the foundation for her despair; so the fact that her search for her father doesn't really matter much means that when they do find him, I don't particularly care. I mean, sure, the reunion itself is emotional, but as far as what it means for Meg as a whole person, it doesn't seem to matter at the bottom line. And I think that's a lot of the problem with this movie-much of the emotion is forced and hollow, with the film telling you how you should feel rather than allowing you to feel it. For example, Calvin just suddenly appears on the street with Meg and Charles Wallace and just stares at Meg and compliments her hair. It's incredibly awkward. I also don't understand why Meg is so important. It's made clear that she's smart, like her parents, but not an oddball savant like Charles Wallace. Yet the Mrses (Mrs. Which, specifically) is convinced that only Meg can save the universe from the Darkness. But why? And besides, if the Darkness is pure evil, why is it not a more powerful force? Why is there no dark, tentacle cloud over Earth? Why does it just manifest as jealousy or abuse in humans? I'm sure this is probably explained in the book, but to be frank, I don't remember much about the book when my fifth grade class read it. There are a lot of questions about the universe that are glossed over or brushed aside and it weakens the movie as a whole. So aside from convoluted story and plot (which I can put squarely on the shoulders of the screenwriters) the pacing also feels off. We spent a good 15 minutes of run time on a flower planet, that while quite pretty, doesn't lead us to much, other than Mrs. Whatsit deciding they need to see a Seer (Happy Balance) to find their father. Why not do this in the first place? They waisted 15 minutes of the movie on a flight sequence that had very little to do with the plot or story at the end of the day. And it's instances like this that make the 1hr, 49min run time feel heavily bloated. I sat through Wall-E (slightly over 2hrs) and the time flew by. By the time Meg finally has her Boss Battle with IT, I was ready to head out. They spend the first 45mins of the movie setting up the characters, but none of it feels particularly necessary. If Act I had been shortened into 20 minutes, it would have left more time for them to explore more of the Universe on the way to finding Meg and Charles Wallace's father. Or they could have just cut it down by 20mins and have been fine. I have to say, people are railing on this movie, and it's really NOT that bad. It's pretty heavy subject matter for kids (some pretty heady ideas being tossed around) but if you think your kid will sit through it, then I think it's worth a watch. I wouldn't spend $15 on it, but $5-$8 sure. I also have to say, hating on the acting is a bit unfair. For the Mrses, Nobody, and Happy Balance, they are beings who are choosing human forms so that the kids can relate to them. They can be whatever they want to be. To expect them to be emotionally human as well is unfair, thus I believe that the irritation one might feel with the acting stems from that. I'm of the opinion that it was a directorial choice and should be noted as such. In conclusion: an OK movie. Not great, but not the worst movie I've ever seen.

reviews.review_title: The Neverending Story meets Hook meets The Oprah Show
reviews.content: This movie is basically 2018's version of Hook meets The Neverending Story meets the literal Oprah show. If you go into it with that expectation, I legitimately think you'll like it. It was sweet and weird and two of the four of us cried. I was not one of them. But I had a good time. Plus, it's directed by a badass black female director, stars a mixed race teenage girl, an adopted kid, a biracial couple, and an eye candy teen boy who plays the useless tagalong that girls usually have to play in movies. Oprah basically plays herself, Reese Witherspoon also pretty much plays herself, and Mindy Kaling kind of plays a kindly stoned human Wikipedia that only speaks in quotes. But probably the best performance from this movie is Chris Pine. Sir, we do not deserve you. I think it's also important to remember that this book was freaking weird. So the movie is weird. And I think Ava did a great job translating it to screen. It's definitely a kids movie and has a simple message and a fairly paint by numbers plot line. But you'll probably have a good time and it will probably make you feel nice. So yeah, I recommend it. If nothing else, go see it to support a movie that has less white people than non-white people on screen in a movie that doesn't feel the need to have the word black in the title.

reviews.review_title: A wonderful message with a few wrinkles of its own
reviews.content: I have been waiting so long too see this movie, and for me, it did not disappoint. the message portrayed in "A Wrinkle In Time" is more powerful than any plot or character flaws. However, there were some flaws. At times, Oprah's character felt as if she didn't understand the meaning of what she was saying. the intensity and important tone was not there. I also felt like the climax of the movie came all of the sudden. Boom, here it is, and then it is gone. This was a bit disappointing. A great movie overall to see with kids. The message was by no means undermined by these few flaws. This movie continues to have messages meant for children that even some adults won't understand.

Given all of the one-star reviews, I was expecting an uneven movie, at best. What I got was a beautiful quest narrative led by Storm Reid and a host of incredible actors that actually surpassed the book in its storytelling.Let's be honest. The book was written a long time ago. It glosses over a lot to keep moving from place to place and the final boss would be seen as goofy these days. But while the movie cut some elements, they are ones that would've dragged the plot down and taken focus away from the emotional core. More is explained (more clearly) and more connections between the parents and their children are SHOWN. If you don't cry at some point, you must actually have succumbed to IT.The only weird acting I saw came from Reese Witherspoon, and it makes sense when you figure out what she is. Mindy Kaling did so much amazing background acting, just with her face, and Oprah... well, who couldn't use a pep talk from Oprah on why you should love yourself? Love is the message, and you aren't beaten over the head with it. Love for yourself, love for your family, be a positive force in the universe because darkness is everywhere.You can choose to do and be better. It's a great movie that I will be watching over and over. The extremity of the negative reviews make zero sense. Neither does their inability to understand the plot or realize that no unicorns are in this movie (wait for A Swiftly Tilting Planet). IT WAS GOOD.

The lost dad was a character I barely knew and so for the rest of the movie their quest seemed mundane and arduous. Some of the acting was marginal and painful to watch. The dialogue matches the rest of the movie which is not a compliment. The special effects were okay and there were moments where the movie garnered marginal interest from me but as a whole I think this does a horrible disservice to the source material. I love Oprah and yet she could not carry this movie. Sorry Oprah!

I had read the book when I was in college and had watched the 2003 movie only to be disappointed. I was so hopeful that this remake would be good since now CG is way better but I was still so disappointed. The plot drags along so slowly only to cram in Meg's confrontation of The IT as an afterthought when the writers realized that they had to wrap it up. The movie leaves out so many important parts of the book like why Charles Wallace gets taken over by The IT and the whole part with Mrs. Beast after Meg, Calvin, and her father first leave Camazotz without Charles Wallace. That part is a crucial part for Meg's character development! It's why she is able to go back and save her brother from The IT by using her love for her brother instead of focusing on numbers to keep The IT out of her mind. They completely skip that part about The IT having the power to reach into and control/play with their minds so much too! Ugh. The movie does nothing to explain what is actually going on with the characters and focuses so much on love and trying too hard to get the message across with special effects that it just ends up being sloppily thrown together and waters down the message. They were trying WAY too hard.

reviews.review_title: Did the writers READ the book?
reviews.content: So, ditto everyone here on the actual quality of the acting, directing, costumes (it looked like the Mrs raided a CVS at Halloween!). The multicultural casting was a welcome change and was the only remnant of the original's spirit. When I was a hearing-impaired fat misfit 4th grader, the book made me feel that it was OK to be different, and that bullies and adults in authority were not always right. Camazotz is a totalitarian planet. Maybe the Cold War has gone away, but the threat of being enslaved by evil because of passivity and conformity has not. The kids in the book walk face IT together (they are not thrown in by a special effect dirt cyclone) and it's an astoundingly brave thing to do--but it's preceded by another brave act: the little boy who dares to bounce his ball out of rhythm, and who they later see being tortured into compliance. Meg goes up against these forces and wins, not because "Love is the key to everything" but because she stubbornly refuses to believe the poison spewed by IT. She refuses to submit to the idea that she is unlovable. Mrs. Whatsit says "You have something that IT does not." She discovers that she has love. Sigh. Maybe someday they'll get this story filmed right. In the meantime, if you have a kid, do them a favor: buy them the book.

I absolutely adore all of the actors in this film - unfortunately most of their appearances were a major letdown to what could have been. (Maybe spoilers, but you knew how it was going to end anyway.)This movie is about a misunderstood girl, who is bullied at school by some mean girls, and her father who somehow goes away to somewhere and for some reason some women come from somewhere and kinda help her and her brother find him. Kinda. Actually, they don't really help much at all. And for some reason they're joined by a boy from school that she doesn't seem to know very well. He does nothing. Mostly stand around watching her do stuff.After the movie ended I had SO many questions. Where did they go? Another planet? Another Universe? Another time? How did they get there? Something to do with frequencies apparently. Where did the women come from? The same universe her father was in? Apparently the women somehow help people, I guess. Kinda. Why did the women wait so long to help her?There's lots of visual candy and little kids will probably like that. But there's lots of nothing as well. Also lots of vague warnings and such and confusing things that are never explained and nobody seems to care. They say things like "where are we?" "Were on such and such. "OK". No, it's not OK. Where is that? Is it a planet? Is it in our galaxy? Universe? We'll never know.The performances are pretty bland. Chris Pine and Reese Witherspoon seem to be going a bit overboard to make up for everyone else just standing around talking.It was hard to really care about these characters. The movie wanted you to care about them without really giving you a reason to.I haven't read the books, so hopefully they explain things better than this movie did and if you've read them it makes more sense.Oh. And one last thing. I'm sick and tired of people making up definitions of what a tesseract is. No, a tesseract is not whatever they said it was in this movie.
I wanted to turn it off half way but kept thinking it would get better noooo it did not this movie was all over the place!

Little Meg tried her best, but it wasn't about her, it was about 3 stiff, bedazzled queens who bore zero resemblance to the characters they were "based on." Why invent a green flower-snake when the Centaur is so grand... and why did they go to the trouble of creating Aunt Beast's world and appearance and show it for just a brief moment? I could go on for days.Wasted time, money and opportunity to bring a stellar story to this generation, who might have discovered the splendid book series. reviews.review_title: Movie for kids not for adults
reviews.content: I just can't believe why so much people are so negative about this movie. I watched it with my daughter. To be honest it's not that bed.

...but very close.Overwrought, overlong, and overcome with a sense of its own importance.Even given the melodrama, it could have been made a whole lot more watchable with just some tighter editing - too much of the movie is taken up with standing around talking, and long dramatic pauses that instead of adding to the tension just make it BORING.I got the impression that this film, if not intended to be an update of Never-ending Story, was at least inspired by it; either way, the intention is clearly to be for older kids and of course the accompanying adults. But most kids - of any age - are going to be bored out of their minds, and their parents are not likely to be any more engaged.One or two good lines (Zach Galifianakis's "Thank you. Earth tones" in reply to a compliment on his outfit comes to mind); the three leading ladies ("The Misses") all can be good, but not with these bad parts; the diversity of the cast was unusual, and commendable, and I liked it; the leading kids were all decent actors and nice to look at without being obviously just "eye candy". reviews.review_title: Fantastic Fantasy/Sci-Fi For The Not-Dead-Inside Viewer
reviews.content: I had to sign up for IMDB just so I could write this review and tell people out there that this was not a horrible movie. In fact, we loved it. I felt that the sentiment and the story stayed true to the book and it was so refreshing to watch a story about a girl on a hero's quest. Her acting was great and I personally loved all the Mrs's. It was refreshingly female-focused which was powerful and inspiring.The story is not just about intellect but is also about heart, in a big way. Clearly you need to have a heart to appreciate it. If you are looking for a story about a hero that takes on not only outer darkness but her inner darkness as well to find whether or not she is a hero, you will enjoy this film. It may not be an academy winner but for what it is, it is inspiring and heart-warming.My one complaint has to do with music choices which I feel will date this film which is a shame because the story is a classic. reviews.review_title: 2003 version is a million times better
reviews.content:
I'm not sure why Time magazine had an article stating that is took 54 years to make a movie from the book, because a movie was made in 2003, and it is vastly superior to the 2018 version.
The 2003 version more closely resembles the book. It contains fascinating ideas and imagery.
This 2018 version of the movie is a contrived propaganda-laden movie, very loosely based on the novel (almost not anything like the novel at all). The cast was carefully selected to be multiracial to the point of ridiculousness. The only two white women in the movie are also the only two mean women... hmmmm... what are we trying to say here? 
I like both Meg's, but the 2018 Meg looks nothing like either of her casted parents - even though I think she is completely adorable. Other than Meg's adorability, the movie seems poorly directed. The costumes are outlandishly distracting, to the point where I spent most of the movie wondering why Oprah Winfrey was covered in so much glitter and so many gems to the point that she looked like a sparkly amazon warrior. Later, I discovered that her make up artist was trying to go for a "wispy" look - complete fail.I recommend you avoid this monstrosity of a movie altogether (unless you just can't stand to not stare at a bad accident), and instead - if you really want to immerse yourself in the movie version of "A Wrinkle in Time," watch the original 2003 version of the movie (I found it on amazon).

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as advertised; not as good as it should
reviews.content:
I read this book when I was a kid and loved it. Was looking forward to seeing the adaptation.
It has some serious flaws, but it's not as bad as the reviews make out. It's enjoyable and interesting to watch, with largely good effects and performances by the actors. The reason I give it a lukewarm 5/10 is because of a key failure in the story.
The key message of the film is taken direct from the book: the power of love and family. It's a message everyone can agree on. But the story inexplicably fails to honor the theme in ways that lost the plot for me.
One of the key instructions for the children from the Weird Sisters was to stay together. The kids are on their own in the realm of evil and it's good advice, but the first thing that happens is they split up. Not only do Meg and Calvin lose young Charles Wallace, they don't even seem to notice he's gone. When he suddenly reappears with no explanation they don't even seem surprised.
It's a poorly constructed scene that broke the spell, but it wasn't unique. The people that they love suddenly disappear and no one seems to notice. They suddenly reappear and everyone just blithely trudges onward. It really undermines the story and the message.
That said, there is still plenty to enjoy. Read the book to get a measure of how much better it could have been.

The special effects, locations and sets are gorgeous, the acting, while not seamless, is done very well by the kids in the film. But what sets it apart is why you should go and see it, like, NOW: it's based on a novel about girls' empowerment written over 50 years ago, it's directed by the first (yes! first!) African-American woman to direct a major-motion picture in Hollywood, there's a mixed-race family, a strong, scientist Mom, and a strong and smart girl hero. From what I can see, many of the reviews here (and on IMDB, etc.) seem to be thinly veiled and coded warnings to viewers about precisely those issues...many of the negative reviews are from the same people who gave all of the Harry Potter movies 10 stars, despite those movies' serious flaws. All the more reason to get your family down to the theater. Go see what real women do...and what real girls can do when they grow up. (Hint: they can save the world!)

reviews.review_title: Can be used as 'time out' for naughty kids.
reviews.content: I rarely write movie reviews, but this bad boy deserves one. I read the reviews, but decided to go anyway - the kids wanted to see it, who I should mentioned 'liked' this movie. First thing that bothered me was the odd filming angles and my nightmare... camera shake on flash backs, like we're watching Blair Witch project all over again. Nausea inducing. Second major issue was the acting, the worst had to be Oprah. I felt like I was watching a Christmas Pantomime in some nondescript English town at Christmas. Third, the story telling was terrible, considering this was Disney I am flabbergasted they let it go to production. Lastly, the end scenes where pretty dark, how did these make it in to this film?! At least I can say I've seen it, although I've already forgotten in. It really is a terrible movie. Sorry Mickey!

Having grown up a Black girl who was bullied and a science geek, this movie felt very special to me, and that's personal. But the visuals blew me away. Mindy Kaling looks breathtakingly good. I didn't read the book, so I had no idea what to expect except DuVernay always brings quality. That's reason enough to give the film 8 stars.

Z-z-z-z-z-z-z
It was worse than a snooze. I had shut off the DVD player before it short circuited on this mess. I really loved the book as a kid. Too bad this was done to it.

reviews.review_title: You all are too harsh on this movie!
reviews.content: I've never read the book, though I've known of its existence prior to viewing the film. The writing left a lot to be desired, I found myself confused most of the time and the dialogue was cringe worthy sometimes. Those things aside, it is a beautifully filmed movie. I loved the creative visual choices made. Camera angles and lighting were quite immersive.Oddly enough, being confused added to the otherworldly aspect I felt from the film. It gave me vibes that reminded me of the strangeness in Annihilation. It's a weird comparison, I know. Sometimes watching a strange movie that's hard to follow is a nice getaway from the normal.

I've quite honestly never read the original books, but i feel like if i did it would be a completley different experience! Other than a few well acted sad moments this film was very average. Its quite hard to follow, the characters are so vague and the story doesn't actually make much sense! Don't think i will be watching it a second time....

Bad movie,, even for kids!!
Should have done better with the story and speed of the movie and definitely the cast! The kid, meg looks so out of character and the weird costumed Oprah!

It may not be the exact book, just like I'm sure Harry Potter readers werent too happy with the movies. The CGI may not be perfect, and these are young actors who are just learning. But when you're learning about how the Universe actually works, how there are different dimensions in the worlds, this movie enhances your belief. Listen to every word. Light is the answer; Love is the answer. Watch it with an open mind.
I was so excited before watching the movie but what a disappointment. I literally had to force myself to finish the film, thinking it HAS to get better.......but it never does.

reviews.review_title: Disney goes deep, making such a good movie!!!
reviews.content:
Brilliant Film with such a deep meaning, relating to mental health, depression and topics which Disney has presented to children in a fun but right way. Many people have rated it badly because they don't understand it. However if you look hard enough there is such a good message to children in one of Disney's best films, that love conquers all, and even when you feel alone and afraid, a little bit of light in the world can help you through.
Even if you've crossed this film of your list because of the ratings, trust me when I say that you need to go and watch the whole film and open up your mind, then you will realise it's more than just a predictable kids film, like many say it is, but one of Disney's best works!

Finally saw this movie, and I do not understand all of the negativity spewed toward it. A little girl misses her father so much, and will do anything to bring him back. What a beautiful bond to portray! Wonderful, positive messages were sprinkled throughout the film. Charles Wallace was a delight! Leave the cynicism at the door, and just enjoy the moment this project created.

Im only about halfway through watching this on Netflix and was so bored to tears I had to look up the reviews. It looks like I am not alone. This movie is literal garbage. The acting is so awful you just want to cringe at every movement. Reese Witherspoon and Mindy are just terrible in this and so unbelievable. On top of all that, the movie itself is just so confusing. I am one that normally loves this sci-fi but this is just too weird. Nothing makes sense and there is next to know story line. Waste of time! Save yourself and do not watch it!
The movie has a lot of heart and some of the actors make this watchable but the plot and script are extremely weak. Some of the visuals are nice but they didn't add a lot to the overall story.

I was excited to watch this because I had read the books when I was younger, but overall I was disappointed. The story moves in such a weird way. The ending felt so rushed. A lot of it was really confusing. I probably won't ever watch it again.

It's clear that the director didn't know what he was doing or his vision of the CGI graphics and they're acting I mean Reese Witherspoon felt like she didn't even know how to connect with her character at all the kids were cute but not the rule for them I hope this doesn't ruin their careers

This film sort of wonders about a bit with weirdly connected scenes as if big chunk of the movie (the interesting scenes) are just... missing? Watched with our 7yo and she was bored stiff for most of the film. Shame, because there were some great ideas (I guess, from the source book) but as a film, this did not work.

My brother's gf chose to play this soul devouring movie on during dinner.

Dinner ruined? -Yup.

-Fudge no.

2 Adults a 12 year and a 9 year old rated this movie 9,1,7 and 8 respectively.
Very slow to start and an improbable storyline made this hard to concentrate on. Without giving too much away the premise of the movie was missed and was not reinforced enough. If someone asked me if I could recommend it I would have to say no.

My family and I were hoping for a movie that felt like the book. The tone and pacing of this Disney film is just off. My son was bored five minutes in, and my daughter almost fell asleep. 3/10 stars.

reviews.review_title: Don't pay attention to the bad reviews!

reviews.review_title: I don't understand why such low ratings!!

Has great morals especially for my 13 year old. This movie is not a 1 out of 10 rating!
I was looking forward to this. Disney, adventure, magic. What could go wrong? But it was wierd and boring that I fell asleep. Disappointing.
I just caught this movie on Netflix. Fortunately it was nothing more than a time waster not a money waster. Read the 1 star reviews here, they are MUCH more entertaining than the movie.

reviews.review_title: I just can't understand this movie
reviews.content: I have no clue what is going on. The storyline is so .... naive.... primitive? I just can't understand what's going on. I went to the cinema to see Oprah and Reese Witherspoon.... god the acting was bad. The actors, especially the young ones are just reading the lines. Had to leave after an hour.

The only thing that was interesting in this film was the casting being diverse, thus the 2 stars...but..the music was terrible, and the script deviated so far from the book that it lost almost everything, the entire camazotz act was broken, and they don't tesser to the planet with furry loving blind many armed beings, Mrs whatsit as a human was young and pretty which was lame, she should have really looked like a tramp, only Mrs Who was remotely believable, and why did mrs whatsit turn into a flying eel when she was supposed to be an androgynous pegasus? no flowers to help them breathe... mrs which was just big giant not the mysterious being she was in the books, and oprah is good actor but they gave her a drippy character and cheeze lines... the happy medium scene was totally broken, no mars, no vision of earth no understanding of mrs whatsit having been a star, then in camazotz no sense of the bureaucratic controlling nature of camazotz, no sense of it as a vision of totalitarianism, though the beach party aspect is perhaps more relevant as a vision of happy fascism which permeates our culture of spectacle. again the music swelled with its terrible manipulative emotion, too bad that even though had a good multiethnic and especially african american cast, they didn't get a decent african american score for the film, they should have asked Erykah Badu to write the music.

Forget about those bad reviews you've read and just enjoy the film. 
It's true that it stumbles a bit in certain aspects of screenwriting and filmmaking, but so do many films we call "great". This visual spectacle filled with rich morale passes a very important message to today's society and children: be true to yourself and be good. It also delivers a brilliant performance by none other than 9 year old Deric McCabe (and it isn't even worth mentioning how great Oprah Winfrey is in the movie).
I believe this wave of bad reviews is given to the fact that people read them before watching the movie, and therefore dislike it even before giving it a chance.
Let yourself be transported into the world of "A Wrinkle in Time", and judge the film through your own standards.

First of all, I LOVE the book A Wrinkle in Time so I was wary when this movie was announced. I think that Ava and her crew did a really, really, REALLY good job of adapting the novel. They did have to leave out a few things but of course, that happens. Storm Reid is great as Meg, Reese, Mindy and Orpah as great as the Misses too. The boy playing Charles Wallace is honestly fantastic and I think he's going to be a well known talent when he gets older. It's also a really stunning film to look at. It's colorful, bright and warm. I hope they let Ava adapt the second book too.

I didn't read any of the reviews on this site before seeing the movie nor did I read the book so I'm not one of those people that are butt hurt the movie doesn't resemble the book. In a sense I had a clean slate with the story line and even with that this movie was a bit boring. It's always a tell tell sign when the person you are with falls asleep during the movie. I myself started to when they were in the 'dark' area towards the end of the film. It's one of those films you are just waiting...and waiting..and waiting for the story line to take off and suddenly you realize you are 1/2 half way through the film and this is it...as good as it's going to get. For me the biggest disappoint was the special effects. Being a Disney film (budget) I expected "Avatar" like special effects and except for one flying scene the rest of the movie looked like it was filmed in someone's living room with cheesy backgrounds. I think this is why people think the acting is bad, it's not, it's cheesy at times because of the script and the movie is not very believable because it looks so cheaply put together. A lost opportunity.

Bad acting, poor writing, horible directing... just terrible.
Boring as hell...
Even special effects werent that great.

I honestly do not understand why this movie has such a poor rating from users. My wife and I enjoyed it very much, and it is 100% better than the previous attempt to translate my favorite novel to the big screen.I admit, the pacing of the film is a bit off. To me, however, this would be the only complaint that makes sense. It is visually stunning from start to finish, includes many well-represented moments from the novel, and is exactly what I had hoped it would be.At the moment, A Wrinkle in Time is on Netflix. I would highly recommend everyone give it a chance

reviews.review_title: It's not Hollywood, but lots to learn from and makes you think!
reviews.content: I am just startled by the plethora of negative reviews I've read about this one, here. I wonder, are these reviews from real people or most folks just don't like movies that make you think? It made me think, for sure.I know, it's not Hollywood. It's not a blockbuster, but the acting is OK. The script and the roles are good also. It is not a masterpiece, not an Oscar winning, but it is worth watching it, especially by those who are really interested in these subjects, in quantum physics and time travelling and all.I never read the said book that this movie was made from, which it entitles me to write this review with a fresh eye, I should say. But one thing I have to say regarding this is that a movie made from a book doesn't have to be totally loyal to that book, but should invite you to read the book. They are alike, but also different, but that point is that it helps the book come out even more.When it comes to this movie, each scene takes you really quick from one place to another, from one aspect of the subject matter to the other and the action is pretty fast, I should say. One needs to pay close attention to what is happening, otherwise would miss the whole point.Overall, I give it a ten because of the subject and the symbolically artistical way in which is portrayed in this movie. And I also want to balance the other bad ratings it has received so far, to make it a bit more worth watching.So, be careful! This movie is not for everyone, but for those who are really into searching about this matter.

reviews.review_title: Read all the reviews.... Their true
reviews.content: Nuf said....... Absolutely terrible! When I try to read the book when I was young I never got it. This movie is terrible. Terrible acting. Terrible directing. Terrible script.

reviews.review_title: Fell short in so many ways
reviews.content: I have read the entire Wrinkle in Time book series countless times. It is one of my favorite things to read and I have always loved the story, so I went in with high hopes. Unfortunately those hopes were dashed against the rocks of mediocrity at it's worst.It's very clear that the casting of this movie WAS the story. So many moments throughout the movie were clearly THIS IS OPRAH BEING OPRAH moments (or insert whoever else's name instead of Oprah). The entirety of Zach Galafianakis' role was the aforementioned strategy, with a little feeling thrown in so he can get better roles later. Basically, the character development was non-existent so we are left with a lot of actors being actors.The storyline itself was a strange combination of mind numbingly slow and lightening quick. It was a far cry from the book (I'm not a book purist by any means but if you're going to veer, do it well). The screenwriters even seemed to go so far as to write in completely foreign scenes that did nothing to further the story. They exerted a lot of effort to come up with random mediocre scenes. I gave the movie 3 stars, solely because I applaud their ability create a diverse cast and challenge my personal preconceived idea of who the characters were. I just wish they had been as diligent about making a good movie as they were about having diverse representation.

reviews.review_title: A great movie to watch with the kids or grandkids
reviews.content: I totally enjoyed this movie. It is lightweight and lighthearted. It easily transitions from one scene to another, keeping viewers' attention. It has positive energy and it is fun. The different "worlds" are fun without being creepy and provide a feeling for the fantasy. I enjoyed the characters and the story of personal growth. I think this could become a kids classic and I know I will be watching it over and over with my grandchildren.

I thought with Disney, Witherspoon, Kaling, and Oprah they would have demanded a great movie. Instead I felt like I was watching a late night lifetime, made for TV movie. Poor acting, bad script, and poor graphics made up the bulk of this show. I could have made most this with an iPhone and my 10 year old Mac. Seriously, was this a project for a freshman film major? I'm so mad. I think the most expensive thing in this movie was the adult actress' costumes. I really hate turning a movie off half way through, but kept believing it would get better. Thank you Zach Galifianakis for giving me 30 seconds of entertainment.

reviews.review_title: Don't listen to the book purists!!
reviews.content: Look, I get it. You love a book and you want to see it faithfully retold on film. But hating on this movie simply because it changed some details misses the bigger picture and fails to acknowledge the importance of the spirit of the book over strict adherence to the plot.First of all, the focus of the movie shifts from the relationship between Meg and Charles Wallace to Meg's journey of self discovery. I think this was a great shift, because I believe the book paints a very dated picture of what sibling relationships are like. I think the movie successfully communicates how deeply Charles Wallace and Meg care for each other while simultaneously showing Meg building self esteem and discovering who she is, and finding worth in that identity. Storm Reid was PHENOMENAL.Next, the ending. Oh god how grateful I am that they changed the ending. I was SO disappointed by that BS "power of love" and then it's over ending in the book! In the film, it felt more genuine and immediate-it felt like a fight for their lives. Yes, Meg does still save Charles Wallace with her love, but it's not that easy. It's intertwined with a discovery of love for herself as well as fighting for Charles Wallace.All I have to say about the Mrses is that they where phenomenal, and keep an ear out for a Hamilton reference at the end! Okay, and yes, they changed a lot. They took out the Aunt Beast scene. But was it that important of a scene? Personally I found Meg intolerable at this part of the book, and all they did on that planet was regroup and send Meg to get Charles Wallace. They folded the rescue of Charles Wallace into Meg refusing to tesser without him, and even set up the power of her will earlier in the movie. They also changed the nature of Camazot. Instead of a machine-like city with quotas and statistics and the highest rate of simultaneous actions, it was more a changing planet designed to trap them. At first I balked at this change, but the more I thought about it, the more I realized that the industrial setting from the book didn't really fit the atmosphere of this movie. Now, I'm not saying this movie was perfect. My biggest complaint was how they downplayed Charles Wallace's intelligence. He never even tried to fight the man with red eyes. He just immediately succumbed. I don't think they did a good job of communicating how special and gifted Charles Wallace is, and I get that they did that for Meg's character, but I wish they hadn't done it SO much.There's more I could say, but these are the main points I wanted to make. Please go into this movie with an open mind and heart. Please remember that this book was published in 1962 and it NEEDED updating for modern audiences. Please give it a fair chance!

I don't know if anyone could love the book by L'Engle more than me, or have read it more times. I don't understand why there are so many poor reviews for this movie. I thought it was lovely. The first half hour won me over and had me in tears. Like the Lord of the Rings, another favorite, the movie-makers decided to take out some things and add some new things. It's difficult to make a movie out of beautiful writing alone (such as any movie based on a Jane Austen novel - the more successful ones add more suspense and intrigue). And so, more action scenes were added (there are no real action scenes in the book). I'm no judge of acting. I just know what I like. I did miss Aunt Beast - I thought that section was important to the story because it made clear that Mr. Murray did not desert Charles Wallace, and it explained why it had to be Meg who needed to save him. I missed the earth-like feeling of Camizotz too, because it is a part that always gives me a strange surreal feeling when I read it - this is one of the places where they decided to add more special effects and action. I can't argue with that, and I thought "It" was done in a very interesting way. I loved the paper analogy to love folded over and hidden, and how it was carried through the story though it wasn't in the book - this is an interpretation, a useful device, that made it clear that love was the power that fought the darkness, and was the power that Meg had.
My favorite three minutes was when our projector broke. Slow, boring, underwhelming, and predictable.
The story could have been really good, but the movie was just lame and poorly done.

Not every movie has to be fast and loud. This one is contemplative, heart-felt, original. Go see it with a child, and the magic will get through to you.

reviews.review_title: Great actors doing a terrible job
reviews.content: The worst I have seen lately by far. Don't waste your time.

This movie was a waste of time for the viewers and a waste of money for Disney. I had read the book in my childhood and remember really liking it, but didn't really remember much about it so the movie had a fair chance without being compared to the book too much.But this movie really blew it.It was a bona fide disaster; nothing made any kind of sense. The human characters were just thrown into a standard hero's journey training and mentoring program which is just extended exposition in order to transport them to a world where the movie can make kids like it by giving flashy visuals and whimsical leaf people and try to make intellectuals like it by using the word "physics" to explain movie magic.You would think that a 250 million dollar budget could pay for some high-school student to check that their physics (which they prided Meg on being good at) was actually correct. You think that you can gracefully "generate lift" with your own body to fly without any sort of propulsion? Even if you could fly like this, air would slam into your face so hard you could barely breathe. And why would hiding in a log before getting thrown hundreds of metres away protect you? They should've died from that impact, not gotten off scot-free.The rest of the movie sucks too.

The scenery was beautiful and the actresses used to portray the characters are amazing but the story plot is awful. the movie is boring and the characters are one dimensional, except maybe meg. Too much overacting from the kids, i could not suspend my disbelief.

The story and it's connections into the next scenes makes no sense. With a budget of 100 mill, I can see where the money was spent on CGI and some top billed casting...but you can see even the actors didn't give it there all in their attempts to fill the characters.

The book was magical and moving, with a wonderful message of Love and Light having the power to overcome darkness and evil. The movie, however, managed to replace key story elements with over-the-top special effects that added nothing. An all-star cast couldn't do justice to the book, leaving out major plot points and characters. What a gigantic disappointment.

adults may be Don't like this movie,
