reviews.review_title: A huge disappointment; read the book
reviews.content: I'd read the bad reviews when this film first came out and decided to avoid it but last night decided to give it a go. "A Wrinkle in Time" is one of my all-time favorite books. Having first read it as an adolescent it was a watershed experience for me as I fell in love with it--the characters, the ideas, the thrilling plot. It's considered a YA book, but I've read it numerous times over the years and still love it and its message. Those ideas and images certainly would be very difficult to capture in a film and this one, as many others have said, is a real misfire. Storm Reid seemed to be sleepwalking; the same with most of the other actors. While the book was published in 1962 and contained that time's sensibility, it is erudite and also charming. The updated, PC flavor/characters in this depiction was sometimes laughable and even embarrassing. And that black thing is just "IT," not "The IT."

reviews.review_title: Good Cinematography, OK VFX, and the WORST screenplay since 'The Room'
reviews.content: I'm going to be honest, I wasn't expecting much when I went into this film. I had heard from my friends that it was bad, and I thought it wasn't going to be worth my time (hence the 3/10 imdb rating). And oh man - I was right!The film starts out - - - wait - I can't even remember. I'm not joking - I literally cannot remember how this movie started!There were some things about this movie that I did actually enjoy. Being a cinematographer myself, I try to look out for films that go above and beyond, and are creative in this field. And this film didn't disappoint. I really enjoyed most of the shots. I thought they expressed a good visual metaphor, that looked good on screen.I also liked the costumes and makeup. I know there probably won't be any oscar buzz around these categories, but I thought they were very well done, and got the message across.Now, lets get into the---other things about this movie. Although in some scenes good, I thought the visual effects in this film were surpassingly mediocre. I mean - It's not 'Justice League' bad, but there were times were the amateur-ness distracted from the story.I also think the acting was also very amateur. Now - I love Opra. She's great. But there was something about this performance which really made me wonder - 'Wait - that's OPRA??!!? Wasn't she a good actor once?' Storm Reid was OK. I think she has a lot of potential - and this movie just wasn't her time to show it. I HATED Calvin. I thought he was a totally unrealistic portrayed teenager that does not and will never exist in the world of teenagers.Now, this review has already gone way to long. But there is one last subject in which I would like to touch on. That's the screenplay. WOW. I had no Idea I screenplay could be this bad. I mean - this is almost 'The Room' bad. I haven't read the book, but my friends who have, have told me that a 30 page-longer section (THE CLIMAX) was entirely left out of the movie. reviews.review_title: I read the book, loved the book. I watched the movie, loved the movie. They're different animals.
reviews.content:
I read the book a long time ago as a child, and then again as a teen, then again as an adult, and again as an older adult. It has always stuck with me and is a favorite of mine. It's a feel-good book, with classic elements of Light vs Dark, Good vs Evil, etc. It relates to kids who are feeling bullied or worn down by social problems, awkwardness in the teens, adults who make mistakes, and feels like a very empowering book to young adults who just want to have an adventure, and fight the good fight on their own.The movie also accomplishes that. It takes a group of kids and young adults and sends them across the galaxy on a mission to save Meg's father. It has all of the elements of a grand adventure, with gorgeous scenery, magical moments, and an ominous, dark presence to fight.I think what people are having trouble with, especial die-hard fans of AWIT, is that most of the book is centered around Meg and her internal dialogues. Her POV is very heavily personal-experience driven, and that's very hard to do visually. For instance, Meg doesn't like tesseracting in the books, because her body goes numb, and it feels like her entire body has been asleep. Coming out of the tesseract is the reverse of that process. So...how do you *show* that in a film? You can't. But the image in people's heads who have read book think they have ways to portray that sort of thing, but it's only relevant to themselves. And when they don't see it on the big screen, I think they get a little angsty and disappointed. I was not disappointed, and I understand a lot of the choices they had to make to bring such a book to the screen. Some wishes for the movie:
The Aunt Beast sequence I feel would have been very important. It was a game-changer that would have given the audience a moment to see Meg turn herself around. I think the trauma and recovery would have been a good sequence to have. I think Meg's sudden self-empowerment is a bit too sudden.The ending fight in the giant...brain?...of IT felt over too fast. The book does it masterfully with a lot of buildup to Meg's sudden realization of the weapon she has that IT does not. I think skipping that important point damaged the ending, and her screams of "I love you!" lost a bit of their edge. And I really loved the line in the book about "She could stand there, and she could love Charles Wallace." I wish they had incorporated that somehow, because it always brings me a smile at that turning point. I don't think they visually gave her that realization and turning point. They just focused on her faults and then love, and then suddenly Charles Wallace was free.Central Central intelligence was tossed in there, but was never really explained as to what it meant. I think either an entire removal of the concept, or an explanation would have been better than just a throwaway line for the fans.Man With the Red Eyes wasn't nearly as menacing enough. Too jolly, not enough bite.More emphasis on the mind-control that was happening with IT. The heart-beating rhythm wasn't emphasized enough.In the prison room, I feel Calvin was underutilized. He was essential to distracting Charles Wallace, so that Meg could use Mrs. Who's glasses to get inside the prison in the book. I wished they had had a better confrontation between Calvin and Charles Wallace, the kind of mental battle I thought would have spiced up that scene a bit more.I gave it 9 stars due to the wishes, but I thought it was a great movie.

One thing that should be noted when making a book into a movie is that it should offer something to fans of the book and also be friendly to someone who hasn't read the book. I have never read the book. Going into the movie, I expect it to tell me what exactly is happening, not assume I know what's up from the book. While watching, I just felt like I was missing huge chunks of information. I knew nothing of what was happening or of the world this story took place in. I assume we are supposed to know as much as the main character, Meg, who seemed to know nothing as well. That said, she was much more... "accepting" of what was happening than I was. I don't know what Meg is like in the book, but in this movies, she is just an awfully boring and passive character. She obviously doesn't want to be on the adventure, but she also doesn't resist it. she just lets it happen and shows little reaction to any of it. Even when she is showing emotion, if you can call it that, it's so forced. I don't know if they cast the wrong actress or the script was written poorly, I just know what I see and it sucks. It especially disappointing because they used a black girl. They could have written her so much better, gotten in some meaningful representation. I don't want to relate to Meg. She's a flat character and offers positive qualities to the table.Going back to not knowing anything about the story, I didn't even know what was happening half the time. Who are the weird ladies? Who is Whatsit's boyfriend?? Is this about time travel???? I just didn't know. Not to mention that they presented the strange ladies as important characters that just left the kids on their own??? And why are they named what they are named? Why did Charles Wallace know them? And now to move into the petty problems I have. Starting with names.Charles Wallace. I assume this is more an issue carried over from the book. In which case, I criticize the book as well! I get it, OK? people can have two first names. My mom and some of her siblings have two first names. But no one goes around using both of them. That's such a mouthful, and an earful. I don't want to hear them yelling that kids name over an over and over again, its long and annoying and frankly unnecessary. Just pick one! Or better yet, just give the kid a nickname! And Calvin? He added nothing to the story other than some heterosexual tension. And there shouldn't be ANY sexual tension cause these are kids and also there is no time for that, they are on a mission. Also, I just don't like his name. It's not a bad name. I just don't like it. It doesn't suit him.Secondly, oh, and this is truly my favorite. Ms Who? And her only speaking in quotes? Because she's too smart to think up her own words? First of all, that sounds pretentious. Secondly, it sounds stupid. It doesn't make her seems smart. It makes her seem... what's the word? I don't know but not coming up with an original thought and instead opting to use famous quotes is the most unintelligible thing I have ever heard. I'd have been fine if she did not have the ability to use her own words, sort of an echolalia situation, because that adds something meaningful to the character, maybe someone can relate to that. But that is not the case. She is capable of original thought and chooses not it. And some of the quotes she uses are so cryptic! Its more cryptic than cryptic can even be! But that just might be me being stupid. But if I recall, this is a kids movie. I would hope they could make the quotes easy for kids to follow along to.I think the message of the story is to love yourself and know that you deserve to be loved by others but... I only got that through what Meg said to her brother? The message was barely shown in the movie, at least not in any meaningful way. You had bits and pieces where Oprah told Meg that so many things had to happen for her to be born just the way she was, but it seemed like a passing moment. That it would not be a major thing. And it never was. I didn't feel Meg's struggle to love herself. She was always more caught up on her father and anything she said about not liking herself was just words. It wasn't until the end that I thought, "Oh, that's the moral of the story?"All in all, I felt the movie really missed the mark. It's flaws left me uninterested in the movie and it really was a waste of time.

Let's start off with how unfaithful it is to the book it's based off of: Entire sections from the Wrinkle In Time book are cut out from this movie. For starters, instead of finding Meg's father by going into the Camazotz headquarters and having to fight the red-eyed man inside and Charles Wallace under his possession, the part of the movie on Camazotz is restrained to completely boring borderline filler. Eventually they reach what the movie calls the Camazotz headquarters but it's an empty room where Meg's father is just sitting up in another empty room connected by an invisible staircase. Another big change is that the planet Ixchel is completely removed from the movie despite being a major part of the book without any attempt to even replace it. Even more randomly it seems they changed the introduction and conclusion specifically to highlight Calvin as a love interest. Another issue that sinks the movie: The visuals do not live up to the book's descriptions. The beautiful creature described on Uriel literally looks like flying cabbage in the movie and Camazotz looks less like the madness described in the book and more like a generic small town neighborhood. Possibly a bigger issue than terrible illustration or terrible adaptation, however, is terrible pretentiousness. The movie as a whole has this attitude that it's woke and deep with the flashbacks of bad things happening on Earth and the semi-vague descriptions of IT that make the whole thing play out like the protagonists are on an ego trip. I had to stop here because I'm late for something but yeah this movie sucks.

reviews.review_title: My Wrinkles go in other directions...
reviews.content: I loved this when I went to see it in the theatre, so we bought the DVD. This month we lent it out to a young couple and they pointed out the commentary, so we pulled it out and watched it again, and it has aged really really well. It's amazing.Okay, so the book was about a white family in New England, but that was what "families" looked like to Madeleine, so that's what she wrote. Now it was a mixed race family in L. A. And all along the way the things that the book made impossible to turn to film, they transposed it to 21st century modes. Who would want a "pulsating brain" in a room for "IT" today? That would be so Dr. Who and this was Disney.This film honours L'Engle's intents as I understood them from the book in every way I could imagine and I am disappointed that its absolute commercial failing meant that the set up for Wind and maybe Tilting Planet will never come to be, when I'm sure that this nucleus of actors could have made it sing if they'd been given the chance.... but the market has no brain, it doesn't love, it's not God: all it can tell you is the price of lunch...So be it. Look for me somewhere out beyond Ixchel and Uriel.

At first I thought a good editor might have saved this film by cutting it down--but it's not three hours long, it only seems that way. All of this is sooooo obvious and didactic. No sense of wonder. No excitement. The best we've got is Reese Witherspoon, who seems to be in a different and more whimsical movie but who really doesn't have anything to work with. We watched about 45 minutes, then skipped forward to the end, which also was slow . . . slow . . . slow . . . and uninvolving. Duvernay's "Selma" was much more interesting, but also played somewhat fast and loose with the material (making LBJ a antagonist to ML King rather than an ally). This film also seems not to be the book it was based on.

reviews.review_title: When the student is ready, the teacher will appear.
reviews.content: I thoroughly enjoyed A Wrinkle in Time. Yes, I gave it a 10. I understand the transformation journey and how the universe will manifest my deepest desires as a result of my thoughts and intent. I believe in guardians, guides, and angels. A Wrinkle in Time was exceptionally profound and enlightening. Ava DuVernay, thank you for capturing the essence of spirituality in the movie. I felt Oprah channel what she has learned about life through her personal experiences through her character. Witherspoon's character and personality...definitely a mirror for Meg. I understood the quotes throughout the movie. I'm a Disney fan and always enjoy their movies. I've been taught if you listen long enough you will learn something new every day. Watching A Wrinkle in Time today proved that. This movie will reach the intended listener and audience it is designed to reach. I am one of them. I relished the fact that there were only 4 people in the movie today. Silence and peace to absorb the numerous lessons the movie offered.

I almost didn't watch this movie because of the low reviews, but I am glad I did. A wrinkle in time was my favorite book growing up and I will say that the movie was extremely true to the book. I was impressed. I could see if someone did not read the book and watched this without any background they might not be able to follow it or understand it but for those who know the story I think it was done very well. I'm not saying it should win an Oscar but i will say it does not deserve the hate - I'm glad I watched. It brought me back to my childhood. If you liked the book, give it a chance!!Also - Chris pine is the dad!! Can't do better than that casting.

reviews.review_title: Overall I enjoyed this movie, but it was difficult
reviews.content: In general, I really enjoyed this movie but there was a lot that made it very difficult to enjoy. It was a heartwarming, encouraging story with a great cast. But the directing/editing made it hard to follow sometimes and easily took you out of the story. I honestly thought every performance was great but the one that stood out to me was Storm Reid as Meg. Some of her scenes really blew me away. I also enjoyed each of the "misses" immensely. The story was great but the writing sometimes felt stunted with very little world building. My girlfriend was confused throughout the entire story. I just felt like the story could've gone so much further while explaining a little more along the way. The graphics were great but some of the editing/directing made it feel chopped up and inconsistent. Lots of extreme, extensive close ups. In particular, a lot of the music choices really bothered me. Maybe it's just me but adding modern music with lyrics in a sci-fy fantasy movie really takes me out of the story and cheapens the whole thing. It felt like we were constantly switching from an inspirational fantasy movie to a teen drama. Just pick one.

I have not read the book and have no idea what the storyline is MEANT to be. I have heard the movie is a trainwreck but not in what way. I don't like fantasy and went into it not expecting to like it but am pleasantly surprised. I think the difficulties the children experience when their father disappears is well portrayed. I like how the boy goes off at the teachers for their idle gossip about something that is so deeply personal to him (the disappearance of his father) and sticks up for his sister who is being systematically bullied since their father's disappearance because of her vulnerability.. He is promptly called crazy along with her for which his sister retaliates and is told by the incompetent principal that it was an unprovoked attack and that she is trying to use "her father's disappeared" card for four years as an excuse for her aggression and is told to cut it out.It is later revealed the principal was indeed selected over better candidates for the position,. Then the movie moved from social justice themes into the trippier themes of time travel and the timeless fight between good and evil. (People criticise that it didn't show the father and friend tessering back, but everything obvious thing doesn't need to be spelled out in a movie. They tessered back the same way the brother and sister did).. Meg stayed back to rescue her brother that had been possessed by evil and it could only be overcome with love. Meg had to face all that was dark and hidden about herself, all the things she didn't want to accept about herself to be strong enough to save her brother. Only the strength of pure love could overcome evil and she achieved that. People may think that is corny but in my 50 years, I have only got strong by facing my weakness and I have only overcome evil with love. The themes are pretty solid for me. That is my lived experience. I actually liked the costuming. I liked seeing what they would do with the makeup, the clothes and the transformation into other creatures. If people are so disappointed with the movie, the book must be outstanding or just not focus on the themes of social justice and good vs evil as much - or has it's qualities in another area that the movie missed and disappointed viewers. It held me all through and I enjoyed it.
Don't mind the negative comments here. A good movie with a very clear message. Fun, entertaining and great family feel good film.

This was a really great movie. It adheres pretty well to the story in the book and was captivating. The cinematography was beautiful; they make great use of CGI to depict the alien worlds, while still maintaining the realness of the main characters. I also thought the pacing was good. I was worried it was going to move too slow, but it ended up moving slow in the parts where it should and moving fast where it shouldn't.I liked the unconventional cast, though maybe Oprah didn't need to be in there. In the book Meg is supposed to be awkward, so people who are saying she can't act are just misunderstanding how she's supposed to be acting. The story is about embracing your faults and figuring out a way to use them to succeed in life; it wouldn't have worked to have Meg be swashbuckling.The main difference between the movie and the book is in the movie IT is actively trying to get them, whereas in the book IT is much more passive. I didn't mind the change. I think the PG13 rating confused some people-- this is a definitely a kids movie, but one that grown ups can also appreciate.

I had never heard of this film or the books. I will now be reading the books as the idea this film was based on looks to be amazing. The film however, I had no idea what to make of it so I'm glad I didn't read the books first.The thing is, to a layman who has never read the books, taking this film as it is, it could have been something fantastic. Really. There are some moments in this film, albeit small moments that the dialogue is exquisite and really made me sit forward and think. In fact at one point I was even nodding in agreement with what Oprah was saying about how the main character got to where she was. There were a few moments like that that saved me from turning it off. There was also other visual moments that kept me watching, like her last leap through space/time to get home. It such a shame that Disney has taken another, what I'm sure was a, literary masterpiece and tore it to shreds to make a quick buck to add to the billions they already have. Shame on you Disney/producer/director but well done to everyone else who was great in this film. Thank you for restoring my faith in books, I will be visiting this series soon.
